151373740.review:
Of all the Devil May Cry games, this is the one I always come back to.
The gameplay is smooth, slick and fast, the learning curve and difficulty are just right. If you prefer a challenge, Heaven and Hell and Dante Must Die difficulty are there, but for gamers new to the genre, or Devil May Cry series in general, this is probably the best starting point.
The story is great, the characters are well written and the music (especially Combichrist, the reason I initially bought it on release day for the Xbox) is perfect for the atmosphere and ambience.

(I know it's an unpopular opinion, but the dark-haired Dante is much cooler than the original! :) )

149651797.review:
I know a lot of hardcore DMC fans didn't like this game, it's a reboot and deviates from the rest of the games art styles and stories. Despite that I love this game, as a standalone experience it's a lot of fun. 

Ignoring any grievences you may have with the story of the game, it has a great combat feel for when it came out. Probably the smoothest in the series at the time and has an interesting twist on how the different styles and weapons play just swapping based on the triggers and d-pad on controller. Also the music is great: 

In relation to the other games I'd say this game changes the music genre from metal/rock to punk, that applies to the music and art style and I love it.

I played this game as a kid when it first came out, sneaking downstairs in the middle of the night to play when my dad got off, so I've got a lot of nostalgia for this game. Keep in mind this was one of the first games I'd ever played and my first Devil May Cry so I'm definitely biased. I'd recommend it though if you can get it cheap, it's only like $5 on G2A so worth the buy.

147248807.review:
DmC Devil May Cry was a decision made by Capcom to reboot the Devil May Cry series when Devil May Cry 4 didn't meet their projected sales. The idea was to reboot it to appeal to a primarily American audience, much like they were attempting with other reboots so that they could grow the franchise. The result was a mixed bag among fans. After playing through all of the prior DMC games, excluding 2, as I'm planning to play it last, I understand the fear that players were going through, especially since they were expecting this to replace the original series and for the questions and setups created by Devil May Cry 4 never to be finished. No matter if that's what Capcom was planning or not, we ended up getting a Devil May Cry 5 from the funding of this game. So, knowing that this didn't replace the original series, I believe that this game was reviewed a little too harshly. 

This game, unironically, has two of the most creative levels I have ever seen in a video game, and I recommend buying this just to see those two levels. I won't spoil them, but I will say that if you have any experience with epileptic seizures, then you should avoid this game at all costs. Traversal is more fun than it's ever been in the series, with Dante having the ability to glide and grapple hook around levels, and even use the grapple hook to pull platforms. There were challenge missions based around traversal that I had no issues with due to how smooth it is to traverse around them. The iconic backtracking of the series, where the player could return to previous areas unless the path behind was destroyed (often signalling an important boss fight coming up) is missing from this game, but you still have the ability to replay prior levels if you need to grind to get more powerful for a boss fight, although I didn't find them to be too hard in this game, as they were mostly easy to read and dodge if you know what you're doing. 

The story's okay, but quite a few scenes are filled with a very cringe-inducing amount of profanity, but it's very easy to shift past, for the most part, as it can be pretty funny in some occasions. There are a few cutscenes present that are extremely cringe-inducing, seeming to think that including sex randomly makes the game more mature (I don't hate sex scenes, but one in the middle of this game is extremely out of place in this game), but they can be skipped since the cringey cutscenes provode literally no exposition.

The combat itself might be the smoothest any Devil May Cry has had, being extremely streamlined for easy combos, but the placement of the dodge buttons on controller (bumpers) are a little distracting since they're above the triggers, which are used to keep your non-sword weapons active. The use of holding buttons to change between three weapons is very creative, and prevents the spamming of one button, like in DMC4 and DMC5, to swap between several weapons to get what you want. There's a controversial feature among fans where a few enemies (who appear more in later difficulties) present in the game can only be harmed by one type of weapon (angellic/demonic), and they tend to throw multiple of them at you at once, which kinda sucks, but they didn't get in the way of my overall enjoyment (will update this when I finish the other difficulties)

Overall, this is one of the most creative games I've ever played, and I'm glad I played it, but it's certainly NOT Devil May Cry.

146678118.review:
This masterpiece, the studio's and developers' [i]Magnum Opus[/i], lets you play as [b]El Donté[/b], Dante's mentally challenged counterpart,  in a reboot to the series. 
Now, a many years later, it's easy to see why this was a bad idea. This game is [i]too good[/i], there is no way to continue an incredible story arc like this, filled to the brim with interesting and relatable characters. 
It makes [i]Homer's Iliad[/i] and [i]Odyssey[/i] look like the work of an illiterate cave troll.
How does one improve upon perfection? 

Let me justify and explain;
 Beloved character [b]Virgin[/b]( Vergil's alter ego ) is changed for the better in this reboot, I did not know what I had been missing until I experienced it.

A good example is the scene where he performs an act that truly fits his established character, and causes him to ascend into the realm of literary perfection... 
In a cut-scene Virgin is performing a [i]long range, high-precision feetus deletus[/i] using a [b]50. cal[/b] [i]sniper rifle[/i]. 
Nothing less for [b]Vergil[/b], the [i]quirky, gun-crazy maniac[/i] we all know and love.

The scene continues with the demon mother weeping for her recently vaporized [i]Hellspawn[/i], holding her belly as [i]gore, viscera[/i] and [i]liquidated demon baby[/i] leaks out between her fingers, Virgin then decides to show us his compassionate, and artistic side...
By creating a [i]painting[/i], using the [b]pavement[/b] as a [b]canvas[/b] and [i]the insides of her head[/i] as [b]paint[/b]. 

Personally, I think that in this scene the dev's wants us to reflect on the [i]unjust violence[/i] that the [b]watermelon population[/b] experience, each and every day in today's society. 

This is but a [b]small example[/b] of what you'll experience in this [i]amazing[/i] reboot of a cult classic, [i]Deviled Eggs Why[/i]. The team behind it are [i]adored[/i] and will forever be known throughout history for their amazing work, and because they told the [i]fans[/i] of the original series to '[i]f*ck off[/i]' after they received criticism that the game was [i]unfaithful[/i] to the original series.
After all, they made the game [b]THEY[/b] wanted to make, and couldn't care less about [i]filthy plebs[/i] whining... I think we can all agree that the studio was [b]100% in the right[/b], and that we should [i]shut up[/i] and [i]throw our money[/i] at them. 

[b](The gameplay/ combat and music is really fucking good though, I recommend it 11/10)[/b]

DmC Devil May Cry Review

Review is after completing the main game on single player and the Vergil’s Downfall DLC

[hr][/hr]

My first Devil May Cry game, and as such I have no idea about the previous games and do not have any benchmark to compare this game to.

[b]Highlights:[/b]
Smooth platforming sections and challenges
Great boss battles
Good mini boss battles
Fluid combat
Grapple among enemies all the time
Exciting skill upgrades
Wonderful weapon types
Colorful art style and graphics
Interesting story about angels and demons
Bombastic soundtrack
Responsive camera
Good for casual gamers as an entry point to Devil May cry

[b]Lowlights:[/b]
The game requires VSync to be turned on, else it sadistically heats up the CPU and GPU. Be warned.
Some optional challenges are frustrating.
Limited outfits and skins for Dante and his weapons
Limited characters in Dante, Vergil and Kat.
Annoying flying enemies that cannot be locked on to
Dante’s Devil Trigger was not used much as it makes enemies hard to reach


Overall Score 7/10

145638251.review:
Absolutely fucking phenomenal.

This is Devil May Cry with fixed controls. The lock on is removed meaning you can now effectively switch between targets on the fly and Dante actually does what you tell him to do.
You do not have as many weapons and combos as you can do in other DMC games, but the ones present here cover anything you may wanna do and all blend in seamlessly together.

Dante is stronger than ever, now able to effectively fight groups of enemies and staying in the air for practically forever. Your hook weapons allow you to pull your self to enemies and enemies to you and are always available. Dash abilities like the Stinger have much longer range and can be animation cancelled to keep the flow going.
All of that allows you to be much more aggressive and agile. The enemies are also much more aggressive and stronger to compensate.

The level design is absolutely ballistic. Basically nothing makes sense there and it's all for the better. Music is metal mixed with dubstep which is arguably the best match you can have.

This game got a lot of hate when it came out and many still hate it to this day. Well all of them are full of shit. Game is fantastic and you won't regret playing it.

Because in nephilim enemies dont die faster, allow you to combo more and i played a lot of gamed that require to prioritize dodging. Definitely bot that bad of a game some people made it out to be.

I bought this game a long time ago. While scrolling through my library today, I thought "hey, why not? why not try something new?" 

And yall.... I tried. I tried SO HARD to like this game that I continued on sacrificing my hours hoping it would get more interesting. Nope. I just cannot click with it. The story is ok, the controls are okish (I'm playing with an Xbox controller) but the main character. Oh boyyyyyy. 

One of the most unlikable personalities I've come across in a game. And I'm not even talking about his looks right now because I'm actually ok with it. This is the FIRST game of this series that I purchased and played. I didn't even know who Dante was before opening up this game (I'm a huge fan of RE though, esp 2, 4, and 7 so I wanted to branch out and try other Capcom games. Plus this game looked similar to Bayonetta, which is another game I love).

Besides the main character, I also didn't like the platforming setup. There's not much to say about it. It feels annoying having to jump and shot in the right position to get points while aiming for the red sacks. I couldn't get to a couple limbo souls because I couldn't reach those areas even though I'm pretty sure I was supposed to be able to reach it. And the jumps kept not registering on my end when he was going to and fro floating platforms. It got frustrating that I took a break for a couple hours to eat. 

Sorry to all the die-hard DMC fans but I just don't get the love for this game. I will try the originals though, just to see if this one really was just the bad egg of the basket.

Now all that being said, It is on sale right now. If you DO want to try it just be warned that the refund button should be the second button you press after the uninstall. Edit: and TIME THAT BEFORE 2 HOURS TO MAKE SURE YOU CAN BE ELIGIBLE FOR THAT REFUND! (I'm not eligible because I bought this game years ago. I envy you).

It would be good for a sequel to this but the fanbase seems split on this one.

142115834.review:
DmC: Devil May Cry, developed by Ninja Theory and published by Capcom, is a bold and exhilarating reboot of the beloved Devil May Cry series. With its stylish combat, stunning visuals, and fresh take on the iconic characters, DmC: Devil May Cry delivers a thrilling and satisfying action experience that pays homage to its predecessors while carving its own path.

One of the standout features of DmC: Devil May Cry is its fast-paced and stylish combat system. Players assume the role of Dante, a rebellious and charismatic demon hunter, as he battles against the forces of Hell. The game's combat is fluid, responsive, and packed with depth, allowing players to execute a wide range of devastating combos and flashy attacks. Dante's arsenal includes an array of weapons, each with its own unique playstyle, as well as his iconic demon and angel modes that grant him additional abilities. The combat system rewards skill, timing, and creativity, providing a satisfying and exhilarating experience for players who enjoy mastering the art of stylish action.

Visually, DmC: Devil May Cry is a treat for the eyes. The game presents a beautifully realized gothic world, with stunning environments that seamlessly blend gritty urban landscapes with twisted demonic realms. The attention to detail in the character designs, fluid animations, and dynamic camera work creates a visually striking and immersive experience. The visual aesthetics perfectly complement the game's intense action, enhancing the overall impact of every fight and traversal sequence.

The narrative of DmC: Devil May Cry is a fresh reimagining of the Devil May Cry lore. It delves into themes of identity, corruption, and the struggle against oppressive forces. The writing is engaging, with witty dialogue, memorable characters, and a thought-provoking storyline that keeps players invested in Dante's journey. The game's narrative serves as both a standalone experience and a love letter to longtime fans of the series, offering a new perspective on the iconic characters and their relationships.

The sound design in DmC: Devil May Cry is exceptional, further immersing players in the world of Limbo. The sound effects are punchy and impactful, enhancing the weight and intensity of each attack. The voice acting is stellar, with strong performances that bring the characters to life and add depth to their personalities. The energetic and adrenaline-pumping soundtrack perfectly complements the gameplay, driving the action forward and heightening the overall experience.

DmC: Devil May Cry also introduces new gameplay mechanics and level design elements that keep the experience fresh and exciting. The game features imaginative and dynamic environments that shift and transform, challenging players with clever puzzles and platforming sequences. These elements add variety to the gameplay and contribute to the game's overall pacing and sense of progression.

In conclusion, DmC: Devil May Cry is a bold and exhilarating reboot that successfully revitalizes the iconic Devil May Cry series. Its stylish combat, stunning visuals, and fresh take on the characters breathe new life into the franchise while paying homage to its roots. Whether you're a longtime fan or a newcomer to the series, DmC: Devil May Cry offers an electrifying and satisfying action experience that will keep you hooked from start to finish. Embrace Dante's rebellious spirit, unleash stylish combos, and prepare for an unforgettable demon-slaying adventure.

141392720.review:
En definitiva es uno de los mejores hack ‘n slash disponibles en la actualidad. Su apartado artístico apoyándose en nuestra realidad ayuda a sumergirnos en su atmósfera aprovechando a criticar duramente el capitalismo, borreguismo o la vanalidad de nuestra sociedad. Una jugabilidad adictiva en intensos y profundos combates con la oferta más profunda de la saga hasta ese momento, así como en una navegación dinámica por escenarios donde se nos obliga a utilizar muchas habilidades y herramientas en un complejo plataformeo.

El juego quizás peca de sencillo, por eso se recomienda jugarlo en la mayor dificultad, sobre todo para veteranos de la saga, pero la gran variedad de enemigos, de escenarios y de posibilidades que ofrece siempre lo hacen divertido. La narrativa trabajada es la que más engancha y mejor nos cuenta las personalidades de cada personaje, sumergiéndonos de lleno en este cuento de los orígenes del atractivo Dante. Por fin empatizaremos con él y entenderemos mejor su relación con su familia, otros interesantes personajes y los demonios. Sólamente hay un puzzle, basado en alinear determinados motivos, una pena que no apostaran por alguna prueba de este tipo más para aportar más variedad al conjunto. Además, esta vez no hay relleno intrascendente ni repetición de niveles como en los dos anteriores juegos, siendo una aventura que va a al grano. Ésto provoca que adolezca de cierta linealidad y no muchas posibilidades de exploración, pero la acción de calidad que ofrece supera estas pequeñas carencias.

8’5

Análisis completo: https://yexreviews.wordpress.com/2023/07/05/devil-may-cry-2013/

141235786.review:
I think this game is best evaluated as just a game on it's own, and not relating to the Devil may Cry series as a whole. Mainly because a lot of the reboot changes are weird, but the game is still fun.

For example, the story isn't very interesting. It's very AAA... if you know what I mean. All DmC lore is thrown out the window in favor of all these new details, and it's very disappointing. 

The gameplay on the other hand, is great! The combat feels like a Ninja Theory game, which is fine because it's still fun!. Being able to switch weapons by holding the triggers is a great change, and I'm disappointed it's only in this title and not in DmC5. Not every part of the gameplay is perfect though. Most bossfights are pushovers. If the boss is 2x taller than your character, then they're easy. Additionally, there is a lot of platforming sections, which become instantly boring on the next playthrough.

This game is like the Dark Souls 2 of the DmC series. It's not bad, but when compared to the rest of the series, it falls a little short.

140716286.review: Devil May Cry has remained among my favorite games since its original release in 2001, with its intricate controls, humorous cast and highly addictive gameplay. The story has gotten much better in sense and perspective, and was what drew me to try this iteration swapping from Capcom to Ninja Theory. This was one of the most regrettable decisions I have ever made. While the combat is the best I've tried in a long time, this remains the only improvement. The story is lacking until the end, with an unfulfilling conclusion and an insult to the works of Capcom. The cast, though admittedly talented in projecting the characters, appear to have had a hard time keeping character. While on the topic of characters, Ninja Theory seems to be more interested in mocking the original games and destroying the reputation Capcom built for DMC which is why they most likely took back control over their franchise, and finally the name "Dmc Devil May Cry". What even is that?! What is it supposed to mean? Is it just supposed to be part of the name to make it sound cool or is it supposed to drive the point that it's a "Devil May Cry", like naming it "Devil May Cry: Devil May Cry"? I'm sure Ninja Theory put alot of time and effort into programming this thing, however it just didn't work in there favor. I hate this the fact this game exists and wish I have never played it. My second review on this platform may be 10 years late, and I hope its my only negative rating but it deserve a -10 out of 10, I don't recommend this game for anyone trying to get into this series or at all. SKIP IT!!!! If you value your time and money.

I DO like DmC, but I DON'T recommend getting the pc version. If you can, please get Definitive Edition on console. DE improves the game with features like turbo mode, manual lock on, and a few other things that generally make the game more enjoyable, none of which were added to the pc version. There are mods that fix some things, but they can mess up stuff and there is no way to enable manual lock on. I have played DE on Xbox One, but decided to buy the PC version to try it out.

TLDR: PC version is outdated, Xbox One and PS4 versions are better by far.

139812658.review: This is the first time in a long time that I have fully enjoyed playing a game like this. It reminds me of Bayonetta, but I feel like the controls are far easier to work with. I like all the jabs at corporate greed and the sprinkled in humor is a big plus. I am usually quite bad at games that contain move lists. I was still bad at this game I am sure in comparison to those who can just reflexively recall the whole move list and pound out moves in rapid succession. The difference is I didn't feel so bad about it because my grading somehow was always around SS, S, A and B. In Bayonetta I was lucky if I could survive the levels. I really enjoyed the game's pacing - each level was long enough for me to play a few and put it down. I am very glad that game development studios consider people like myself who just want to unwind, enjoy the story (for what it's worth) without it feeling like a second job. This is the first DmC game I have ever played so I was quite lost as to who all the characters were, but I don't think it took anything away from the game play for me. It was just mindless fun. There were same damn good levels that were very enjoyable. It's funny because it's almost overwhelming with how many weapons and moves there are - I would get confused at times. However, once you get in a groove, the game play flows so well and it has the right amount of story, travel and action - never too much of any, it's perfectly balanced. I strongly recommend this game for some good fun. Looking forward to playing the rest of the franchise now.

139781813.review:
DmC Devil May Cry : Vergil do everything to avoid paying taxes
This is what happen when you handed your Jap IP to a western studio, they created a generic action adventure game instead of a fun spectacle fighter, it's like dark souls without the souls. This game is more like a maybe than a recommended, it's not bad enough for a no but not that good either, go play DmC5 if you have already played other DmCs, ignore this one like it doesn't exist.

If you have never played DmC or have some money to waste then this one is an okay game, the core gameplay is still good, combat is solid, you can use this to kinda get familiar to DmC combat. One thing they did well is that they solve the platforming issue in DmC, platforming feels kinda good in this game, your jumps actually have some forward momentum. Weapon movesets are good, input aren't hard but the double forward in just weird especially on controller, way more awkward than lock-on + forward.

The game has a lot of stuffs I really don't like, I highly doubt I'll ever play this again.
Try too hard to be edgy,cool. 
Why is Lilith look like she's full of botox ?
Main villain is lame AF, a demon in human form controls everything using dept, really ? His final form is just a giant pile of goo with slow and easy to dodge attacks.
Vergil feel useless the entire story and acted like a dumbass in the end, the build up in DMC5 is so much cooler. There's no motivation in this Vergil, there's no POWER, lacking plastic chair is why he sus.
Overly used red and blue colors, hard to even see anything on the screen sometime especially during the chaos of battle, the entire game is either red or blue.
Weapon designs are lame, generic, there's no zing in them, they just look like normal weapons.
The dodge is weird, the first 90% of the animation is super fast but the last 10% suddenly its like slow motion with no iframe.
There is no freedom in combat, you're forced to use demon/angel weapons for certain enemies, too many gimmick fights using demon/angel mode. Unlike in other DMC where you can just use one weapon and one attack to clear the game if you wanted nobody cares. I never felt like I want to do a cool combo in this game, most of the time I have to pay attention to what kind of enemies I'm fighting, do I need to use angel weapon or demon weapon.
the A + X input is ridiculously hard because its required both button to be pressed at the same time without any amounts of delay, they tried to simplify inputs by removing lock-on and style switch but ended up making it harder by having too many inputs overlapped each other while having to juggle between rebellion, angel weapon and demon weapon
Boring generic enemy design, most enemies are just humanoid with some kind of mask or armors, horrible bosses design, literally can't remember a single boss fight from this game and I literally just finished it, it's so boring and uninspired, one of the boss is literally just a giant baby with one of the worst camera angle ever, it's so low you can't see anything coming from the ground because the camera is trying to focus on the head and everything is so fkn dark, the entire boss fight is just fly toward the boss, hit the eyes, pull Lilith out, hits her, repeat until she die. Probably one of the most boring boss fight I've ever had.

overall I recommend this game in the context of it being standalone or a spin off non canon devil may cry game

139145043.review:
I guess this just isn't for me. It isn't objectively bad but it has a number of elements I don't like and in total I just can't say I enjoyed it enough to recommend it.

The lore was very interesting. I kept feeling like I was missing something, probably because this was my first exposure to the franchise. Graphics are pretty good. I'm positive I bought this because of Dante's pretty face.

It reeks of being a console game, and by that I mean there are short, discrete levels, levels are divided up into tiny areas to fit into a console's limited RAM, you are mostly forbidden from backtracking (doors snapping shut behind you), and it makes a big deal out of scoring points like an arcade game. Lots of fighting and areas don't feel very organic - it all feels carefully scripted and doesn't flow naturally. Frequently the game asks me to fight a half dozen enemies at once to try to make me feel badass or whatever, but to me it feels like the game is trying hard to make me have a power fantasy and the fact that I notice it so easily harms immersion.

Controlling the camera is a consistent problem. When I try to rotate the camera it frequently gets stuck on a nonexistant wall, as if to try to force me to have a certain perspective. Never before have I seen a game that fights me so hard with the view. I try to look around and the game just says nope, can't do that. I had to wiggle my mouse a lot and eventually the camera lock would let go but never for long. Nothing in the settings for it either. There are lots of secrets that you can't get on your first playthrough, but I don't judge it to be fun enough to justify playing a second time. Looking for secrets was made more challenging by the camera shenanigans. One level, I think 11 or 12, was taking place in some narrow corridors and getting through that with the janky camera was the worst.

Level 13 and 14 had incredibly irritating flashing lights. Some parts of my display were extremely dark and a few spots extremely bright, with the lights shifting and flashing all the time. It is so hard to see what is going on, and dodging out of the way of something I can't even see for the flashing lights is unreasonable. 

Most enemies feel like they soak up entirely too much damage. I can just keep smacking a baddie over and over and they just never seem to want to die. Bosses are even worse.

Healing is pretty hard to come by; I never got much money to buy healing items and barely any healing drops from defeated enemies.

138863321.review:
DmC Devil May Cry is a wild diversion from the main Devil May Cry series. You'll once again take on the role of Dante in a re-telling of Dante's fight against Mundus and rivalry with Vergil. We're changing up the formula a little this time though. My best way of describing DmC is "what if you asked the world's biggest nu metal fan (Slipknot, Korn, Linkin Park, Disturbed, etc.) to make a DMC game?" Seem interesting? Let's talk about it.

DmC's gameplay is largely the same from the main series. It's a spectacle fighter melee action game focused on weapon-swapping and building up stylish combos to get that juicy SSS (SENSATIONAL!!!) rank. You'll obtain three different guns and five different melee weapons. Your melee weapons include Rebellion at the start, followed by two Demon weapons and two Angel weapons, to represent Dante and Vergil's half-demon nature. I want to talk about the control scheme a little. On keyboard and mouse, your regular Rebellion attacks are on left-click. However, holding down E when you left-click will hit with the current Demon weapon, and holding down Q when you left-click will hit with the current Angel weapon. Scrolling up once swaps your Angel weapon, and down once swaps your Demon weapon, and clicking middle mouse swaps your gun. While initially this controls scheme seemed really absurd, the more I played with it the more it actually seemed very fluid, reducing the amount of time I spent swapping weapons in combat, and I almost wish they kept something similar when they made DMC 5. 

Aesthetically, DmC is very gritty and dark, very appropriate for the nu metal scene at the time of its release. In comparison to the main series focus on Italian architecture and religious/angelic imagery, DmC feels very grounded, American, and demonic. It's not necessarily a bad thing, I would just describe it as different, and in this regard, different is actually good. It feels like a unique take on the classic DMC formula that we had seen four times already at that point. There are some instances where the modern spin feels bad; people often reference Dante and Vergil's outfit design feeling weird and off-putting, and the bold-face text that pops up all over the environment can seem immersion-breaking at times. On the other hand, the soundtrack of nu metal/screamo that plays during combat is absolutely stellar for a fan of said genres. Overall, it's different, for better or worse.

There are some aspects of DmC that are pretty rough though. The story is very lackluster. Despite it more or less being a re-telling of DMC 3, the stakes of this story seem almost silly at times. Dialogue feels un-inspired and lazy, with Dante's usual quips and jabs mostly defaulting to variations of "Fuck you" and "Suck my dick". Vergil is unrecognizable in terms of personality, and only gets remotely close to DMC Vergil in the final mission. The twenty missions you'll do are often broke up very choppily, in a way that makes it feel like a mission often ends on a commercial break rather than a true ending. A fair handful of missions also lack substance, comprised of either parkouring through the city or chase sequences or both, with little story or combat involved. There is in my opinion *one* good boss fight, with the rest either being mediocre or downright bad. Slight spoilers, the final two boss fights are incredibly boring, which is incredible because I didn't know you could make a [spoiler] Vergil [/spoiler] fight boring.

In total though, I'd still recommend checking out DmC. DmC is still pretty faithful to the original series and actually gives a lot of inspiration for the development of DMC 5. I'd recommend you wait till it goes on sale for like 75% off, and I'd recommend you play the entire main series, or at least DMC 5, first. But overall, it's a decent 6.5-7/10 from me, worth a one-time playthrough for the LOL's and the soundtrack.

138589243.review:
Old school DMC player here and........the game is good.

The biggest difference is that instead of a dark gothic horror setting DMC has flashy neon bright colors. But these effects are done very well and will run smoothly on a potato in 2023.

Also the story and non-action cut-scenes are bad, do yourself a favor and skip them. We're here to slay giant demons and look cool doing it, that's it.

Combat is classic DMC, it's as good as the other games. You can counter, dodge and look great while killing enemies.
The animations and art are top notch, the combat flows very nicely. You get a lot of weapons and options and enemies are easily dispatched once you get the rhythm. Bosses are easy, I barely touched my vital stars and even killed many bosses first try.

I remember a lot of hate when this first came out but that was because people thought this was the direction of future DMC games, and they were all wrong. This is the only "re-imagining" of a DMC game. This DMC is a nice extra side quest to the main DMC franchise and is a definite must buy for any DMC fan.

138152869.review:
There's a shit ton to say about this game but I'll keep this short.

I'm not sure Capcom ever had any intentions to canceling the mainline DMC for this version. I'm pretty sure this was a joint effort project between studios to make a "re-imagined" version of the game and holy shit this is one of those moments where you realize Capcom needed to sit down with their audience, hold their hands and have to tell them "don't worry, DMC 5 is  still going to happen, this is just a side project, we're not canceling OG Dante" because I'm pretty sure if everyone went into it with those expectations, they would of given this a chance instead of throwing a tantrum and treating the  game like their unwanted  step-child.

Quick thing. This game has its technical flaws.  I noticed after a fight, the game did not progress, this happened twice in a row  only. Sometimes I'm pretty sure the controls aren't matching what I want them to do entirely but this could be on my end and it was super rare and other little janks here and there. Nothing that made me too upset.

The gameplay is definitely interesting with the angel and demon enemies and trying to play it a bit like a puzzle. It's hell on harder difficulties but it's creative and I gotta give them that. I understand this is 'different' from the rest of the series but the criticism for 'different' is probably from the 'diehard' fanboys who will gladly defend a game that sells a reskined version of its predecessor so I tune them out. I  also hear people say it's too easy and I'm writing this in the middle of a Son of Sparda  run but I do remember it being easier on lower difficulties. But this is again a person to person thing. You will never satisfy everyone.

The  art? Oh GOD it's so good. The music, level design and the story  is actually pretty good as long as you don't bitch about "THIS ISN'T DMC" and realize it's a re-imagining. If you don't like the occasional raunchiness, I get it, it does get a little eye roll in some moments but I feel like the critics of the story are ignoring all the good moments it has and even ignore moments in the story that are plot hints just to shit on it. Dante being edgy? I feel like the word edgy  changes from person to person. Because I think there are people who would call literally every character in every game 'edgy'. 

Look. I'll defend this game to my grave because it simply does not deserve even half of the hate  it gets. A lot of the criticisms I see are -very- immature ("DANTE LOOK'S GEH!") and you should be going into this game expecting a lot of fun in a -very- trippy  world.

"Try opening your mind, it's all a matter of perspective"

136278820.review:
11/10 The only DMC title worth playing.

8/10 story 
10/10 characters, music, graphics, gameplay, bosses, lore, combat, controls, etc.

Ninja theory really made the DMC come alive here, the only one with an actual story, and fun controls

If you want a game with outstanding soundtrack, epic boss fights, a complete rehaul on the outdated controls capcom uses, amazing characters, and a story that binds it all together look no further

100% better than any other DMC title

Replayability 100% the game is meant to be played at least twice.

The characters are amazing
Dante takes a massive update to his combat system making moves much cleaner, and easier to pull off.
Virgil is no longer just a pouty prince on his throne but actually seems like a brother.
Kat is very cute, with some great scenes, and more than just a pretty face like capcom seems to paint their women these days.

The combat update is amazing, no longer do you have to just wiggle the control stick hoping to get the right moves, and switching between weapons has never been easier!

The world building, and level design are fantastic, lots of extras in each level you have to find out how to reach. Every level feels like it actually connects to the last, rather than "I went in a tube now I am here"

The story is a bit on the soft side, but they do an amazing job connecting it all. Plus it is 100% better than capcoms no story at all.

Overall this game did a better job explaining the dmc universe in the first 2 levels, than capcom did with 5 games.

11/10 will recommend every day of the week

135427971.review: As a standalone I believe this game wouldn't be getting as much hate as it does. I would even reckon its the first game I'd recommend for someone just getting into DMC, the combat is simple but has its room for potential. The demon weapons work as very beginner, non combo weapons that pack a punch but in later stages of the game i've only ever used them for Trinity Smash and Snake-Eyes. The angel weapons imo is where the game leans more into juggling, however the combos are pretty simplistic and repetitive at times, with the angel and demon lift a baby could juggle an enemy for as long as they like. The biggest gripe for me was the button layout for controller, it made no sense to me to have two evade buttons by default whilst not being able to map the devil trigger or the jump shoot buttons eg. Rainstorm, Kablooey shots into those buttons. I mean they had a whole ass franchise to work with here for button layouts. Aside from the 'decent' combat, the cutscenes were questionable especially any involving Lillith and Mundus. For the boss fights the only ones that stood out to me was the Bob Barbas fight visually and both vergil fights (main game and dlc) theyre a good bit of fun but i find that vergil randomly walking and doing nothing breaks the immersion. Overall the game is good, far from best but with todays DMC standard from 3 and especially 5 youre definitely better off spending your time on those games.   Cons: Lacks combat polish, story is meh and some enemies bring the combat quality even lower (witches mainly) Pos: Visually the game is great even to this day, missions like Devil's Dalliance, Bad News and Vergils downfall are aesthetically pleasing, the game is a solid start for the genre/series given its simplicity and most importantly. El Donte, Exterminador de Demonios

135098726.review:
The Game:  I feel really conflicted about this game. On one hand, it is a solid action game with cool move-sets but on the other it has so many annoying mechanics and enemies that it makes the experience a mixed bag. Dante has 5 unique melee weapons and they are all very fun to use equally. They give the player many tools to play around and have fun with  but they all feel a bit too clunky. The Ranged Weapons are all horrible and not fun at all to use and they also kinda fucking suck. Overall combat is pretty good but it has many flaws, becomes a bit repetitive, and I would blame that on the enemy design.

 The enemies range from punching bags to extremely annoying ones requiring you usually to use one specific tactic or weapon to defeat them.This makes the game lose its fluidity and forces you to not experiment and just spam whatever is most useful. The bosses except for one (BOB) are mediocre but pretty innocent over all .The art direction in this game is pretty awesome and overall very unique compared to any other game I've played. Limbo is a pretty cool concept and could use a bit more work but overall, really nice to look at.


The story:This reboot of the franchise is known for the completely terrible story and not in a good terrible way. Dante is extremely poorly written and that is a highlight of the story. The way he talks to his enemies is extremely funny. He talks like a 13 year old kid on xbox live and that is very entertaining in its own twisted dumb way. The problem is he only does that for around 5-10% of the time and the rest is just PAINFUL TO GET TROUGH. The story takes itself incredibly seriously and expects you to be invested but I bet you won't give a single shit about any character by the end of the game. Also this game has cutscenes EVERY 30 SECONDS. It tries wayyy too much to be cinematic and it fails drastically. 


TLDR: Solid short action game, would recommend if you skip any cutscene where Dante doesn't talk about how he fucked your mother last night.

6.5-7/10 Interesting game.

134995991.review:
DmC: Devil May Cry is an action-adventure game developed by Ninja Theory and published by Capcom. The game features a new protagonist, Dante, who is a young man with supernatural powers. The game is set in a world where demons and angels exist, and Dante is caught in the middle of a war between the two factions.
The graphics design of the game is stunning. The game features a unique art style that is both dark and gritty. The environments are beautifully rendered, and the character models are highly detailed. The game also features some impressive lighting effects that add to the overall atmosphere of the game.
The puzzle elements in the game are well-designed and add an extra layer of depth to the gameplay. The puzzles are challenging but not overly difficult, and they require the player to think creatively to solve them.
The story of the game is engaging and well-written. The game explores themes of identity, family, and betrayal. The characters are well-developed, and the voice acting is excellent. The game also features some impressive cutscenes that help to move the story forward.
Overall, DmC: Devil May Cry is an excellent game that is well worth playing. The graphics design is stunning, the puzzle elements are well-designed, and the story is engaging and well-written.

134993866.review:
DmC is a top tier Hack and slash game. As a reboot of maybe the best hack and slash series out there this game has a lot to life up to. The game is 10 years old now and even compared to other DMC games this is still a REALLY good hack and slash.

My one big complaint is that the story is really bad. It isn't original at all and the execution of the story isn't that good either. Almost all characters are very boring. A lot of things here are talked about but not explored at all, for example angels, this is something completely new here compared to regular DMC yet the game practically never explored that angle of the story. Combine that with the game ending on a MASSIVE cliffhanger and the story just kind of ends up being bad and getting in the way of the game. If you haven't played a Devil may cry game before you might find some value here but past that it is a waste because there was a lot of potential here due to the interesting setting.

Thats right the setting is actually amazing. Limbo is this dimension that exists outside of the normal world. Thats where the demons live and its an extremely interesting and original setting. Its where you pretty much do all of your fighting in game and it creates for locations so interesting and original that I have almost never seen them before in a video game. Seeing the broken world, having the world talk to you and exploring some really creative locations is seriously incredible. Another part of the setting that I really like is that Vergil is much more of a brother to Dante in this game, in pretty much every DMC game its immediately fight fight fight but here you can explore a much different dynamic which is really cool and has a lot of potential. This unique setting combined with the strong combat give more then enough reason to play this even 10 years later. 

Talking about combat lets get into the meat and bone of this game. Its a hack and slash game and its a DMC game. That means its all about style baby and this game does that very well. DMC is usually quite a difficult game especially at higher difficulties, this game on the other hand is MUCH more accessible. It could be because I played a ton of Hack and slash games at this point but I really felt this was one of the friendliest and most well designed game into teaching you how to explore your options. What do I mean with options? Its simple, in pretty much any hack and slash game you can usually default to some standard combos and do fine. BUT doing that is usually pretty boring, so this game teaches you how to REALLY make use out of all the weapons and abilities you unlock throughout the game. Does an enemy give you trouble? Try out some of the weapons and see how the enemy reacts to that. The only other game that is even friendlier for beginners might be hi fi rush but that also is a much more modern game. As it stands this is a great entry point for people who want to get into hack and slash games or those who just want to chill and enjoy a well put together hack and slash.

There is 1 thing I didn't talk about in the combat or the setting but that is nonetheless very important. Modes, in the 2nd mission dante unlocks the ability to switch weapons/modes. He is the son of an angel and demon which means he gets to switch between both those modes. The controls for this are really great on a controller and allow you to flow between weapons and combos extremely easily.  Switching between mode is important not only for combat but also because the game has a heavier focus on platforming and interacting with the stages. My only regret here is that the angel part of the story and the world doesn't get explored. But this mode switching stuff is really creative and feels very unique to this game. There are a couple of other games that do mode switching as well but I haven't really seen one be this backed into the core of a hack and slash game like this (Outland is a 2D action platformer that also has this type of mechanic). Major props to the devs for thinking and implementing this system in this way.

All in all there are other things I could nitpick about. For example the game auto locks onto targets, great for beginners but for people like me who attack with more intention it can be frustrating to attack the wrong enemy. Some stage mechanics can feel outdated. The game can be a bit too simple at times. Especially compared to modern entries like Bayonetta 3, DMC 5 or Hi fi rush this games complexity can leave something to be desired. But those small things don't detract from the overall feel of the game. DMC is extremely creative and every stage feels fresh and interesting. Combat is executed extremely well with excellent sound and attack design as well as enemies that are admittedly easier but also very fun to kill. If you enjoy hack and slash games I highly recommend this game. If you want to get into the genre give this a go. There is a lot to love here.

134747694.review:
DMC Devil May Cry Review

They don’t make them like this anymore. 

The story and dialogue are absolute gold, it was a pleasure to watch the shit show. This also weirdly enough felt like the first game in the series, and apparently is, this series for some reason has a weird order of game story. As a result I think I might skip 1 and 2. Jump to 3, 4, and 5. But this definitely isn’t a game to skip. Definitely play it first. 

Specifically in the story, I like how there’s twists and turns, and it’s easy to follow. As someone who can be overwhelmed by information, it’s very appreciated to see a game be easy enough to follow. 

Graphics aren’t massively amazing, but it is flashy, and the art design is really good for demons, Dante, abilities and weapons. It’s pretty easy enough to see, but there are visual indicators that aren’t that great, when you get the angel hook and demon hook stuff. It could have done with a text indicator alongside it, as a quality of life. Subtitles are also weird, they’re all clumped together, meaning the next piece of dialogue is in the subtitles, and not paced at all. It’s all one sequences rather than spread out. Also the animations and combat are responsive and smooth. 

But the combat is where this is gold, and this is where it clicked for me. It clicked when I unlocked the hooks. This combat is so satisfying and interesting. Minus the shield and parry enemies, but they are so good. I’ve never found a game with a more satisfying combat system, and there are combos to add on top of that. It isn’t as unga bunga as other games, which isn’t a problem, because some combos are easy to remember. Though I prefer unga bunga, it is easy enough to play remembering just a few combos and upgrades. I played on Human difficulty (The easiest) and it was challenging enough as is. One other issue I suppose is that dodge can sometimes feel like it doesn’t work. And the narrow time window to dodge some enemies makes it inaccessible. This game sorely needs accessibility options to do better really. It’s not friendly to anyone with motor or cognitive impairments. Also not suitable for anyone prone to seizures. A lot of this forced shit is what can really sour games. Because this really feels like a game made with love, but clearly not consideration. 

For some reason I never got enough red orbs to upgrade everything which is a first? This game seems to want you to grind it which is a strange design choice. Once is enough for me to be honest, I don’t feel as though this is a game I’d want to 100%. As I’d get too frustrated easily. 
Voice acting is nothing notable, it’s just fine. Music is good, there’s some metal tracks, some um, electronic? Not sure what you call it. There’s just some good music here, nothing notable though, but nothing insufferable, as I would have worried about with the electronic music, since my sensory issues could be easily overwhelmed by it sometimes. 

But, there are other major flaws I have to bring up separately. 
Firstly, some of the combat and mission design feels very dated, to the point where it's unplayable and unpleasant. Secret missions in particular. Fight enemies in circle. Fight enemies without getting hit. It's not fun. I played on the easiest difficulty for reference since I don't like a challenge, and this was too challenging. Later enemies are stupidly unpleasent to play with, namely those dreamrunners. Enemies that parry are just shitty. And then on the final boss fight, there’s a gamebreaking bug where he just keeps healing and Devil Trigger doesn’t work against him, and can’t be attacked. Either way, another accessibility issue is the lack of a map. I have no idea what instalment of the game this is, because this is my first Devil May Cry game. But it is dated in this aspect, most 2013 games have a map where there are collectables. This one doesn’t for some reason. And given the collectables which by the way, some can only be obtained through later upgrades, it feels very behind in terms of accessibility. It’s a game that requires replayability to be completed, and that feels really unsatisfying as a completionist myself. 

Overall, it’s a good game for a one time play through, but I can’t really say it’s good for multiple. The DLC I never realized existed, feels unnecessary. 

(Note: learnt this is a reboot? What? Why?)

134727823.review:
The first thing you should know is that someone uploaded a 64bit patch on the nexus mods hub for this game, if you're on a 64bit system you're going to want to grab that for some boosted performance, as natively the game is only 32bit.

The game has a bit of a controversial history, but don't let that scare you off. The story in my opinion isn't as good as the main series games, but the gameplay is definitely worth your time. Dante plays like a combination between main series Dante and DMC4 Nero, bringing together a lot of the better aspects between them both. Noteworthy is his ability to use his sword, Rebellion, like a grapple hook on both enemies and certain terrain to either pull himself towards the target, or the target towards him. This gives him the mobility of Nero while having the combo variety of Dante with some of Nero's moves mixed in. The result is very fun.

Overall if you're willing to treat this as its own thing, it's actually really fun. I personally prefer the story of the mainline games, but I will say that this does have some franchise potential if they decided to revisit it down the line someday. Just call it an alternate timeline/universe, problem solved. The story here isn't really even all that bad, it's just different. It's perfectly enjoyable.

This is a great game that was sorely underrated when it originally released simply because it wasn't the exact same DMC or Dante we had before. As a fan of DMC from the initial entry into the series on PlayStation 2, I loved this game. I am glad that years later, people agree that it is a great game that many folks slept on because it attempted to take DMC down a different path. It is unfortunate that when a game could have simply had a different title, that it would've been treated differently from the beginning. But, that's all in the past. This game is great. It was great from the get go. And it is now appreciated more than ever. It was a complete, quality, OG-Capcom feeling action game that had no microtransactions, no monetization, just typical early 2010's add-ons, and most importantly - and this is a big one, and it really nailed it - it was fun to play. 9/10, am still playing nearly 10 years later. The "next-gen" updates it got both on Steam and from being ported to the PS4/Xbox One generation of consoles made it even better than it used to be. I played it originally on Xbox 360 when it was native 720p @ 30fps - and get this, I still thought it was great. haha

The edgy ass story is garbage though. lol Fair warning.

134045172.review:
[h1] An ambitious concept that failed to show it's true potential [/h1] 

DmC is a great game with accessible combat and a relavitely low skill ceiling, combo executions feels great even with a relatively limited arsenal of weapons, what i feel doesn't work is it's identity, it had a solid fundation to work with back when it was revealed in late 2010 but failed to build upon it properly due to fan backlash and pressure from capcom.

Characters feel two dimensional even with their attempts to show more than what's on the surface, this could be due to the game's relatively short duration but honestly it just seems to be a result of bad direction, the plot twist is barely hinted at and as a result feels forced for the sake of necessary conflict and a need to feel true to the original series.

Art direction is shoved in your face from the very start, it's not afraid to overstay it's welcome and you can tell the developers took their time to make the game look as good as they could, it's a testament of what Unreal Engine 3 was capable of, some people might find the colors overly obnoxious but in my opinion this sentiment mainly shows in the orange areas.

The music reflects the attitude of the game, it's loud, abraisive and rebellious, it mainly features Combichrist and a bit of Noisia here and there, it's one the game's better aspects.

All in all this is a great game but it could've been better if only it had more time and a chance to show it's true face, if you know the history of the development of this game you would know what i'm referencing, sadly this will probably never happen as DMC5 released to critical acclaim and blew this game out of the water in practically every aspect, still, if you haven't played this game already you still should, it's still a solid overall 7/10 experience.

133998116.review:
Despite it's harsh reception upon release, DmC: Devil May Cry is an interesting spin on the Devil May Cry series.

Gameplay mechanics such as DMC's popular mechanic called 'Styles' which allow you to change up your fighting style to reflect it. 

I.E Trickster being a style about movement, and Swordmaster about swords, or gunslinger about guns, you get the picture.

DmC: Devil May Cry takes on the gameplay by doing away with that mechanic, and making the game more freestyle, getting rid of the style switching and just reverting to Angel and Demon weapons, which have their own neat powers.

The game controls amazingly, and the gameplay is extremely responsive and intuitive. 

The soundtrack is possibly the best in the series considering this game's reputation, with Combichrist and Noisia producing most of the soundtrack.

The story is surprisingly decent if you just think of it as a spin-off and not an actual story in Devil May Cry's universe.

Overall, a very fun experience and worth the money.

133305521.review:
I remember playing this one when it came out on the 360/PS3 and the backlash was immense. In order to appeal to a western audience, Capcom rebooted the franchise and handed development duties over to a third party, Team Ninja. What we got is a game that is absolutely solid and enjoyable, but feels more like a well produced Devil May Cry clone than full fledged title in the series.

Gameplay is solid, but has been simplified to an extent. Enemies are just as agressive and hit hard still, but they now telegraph their attacks more and dodging is all around easier to do, likely containing more I-frames than in DMC 3 and 4. The stylish action of the previous titles is still here, but now feels quite optional. Spamming the same few combos will still get you a SSS rating if you know how to dodge, so mastery of different weapons isn't a requirement for the SSS achievements for all levels. The non- combat sections do get a bit repetitive, even with kind of fun traversal mechanics and all semblance of puzzles have been removed from this one, not that they were too prevalent in the previous titles. The same traversal tools, basically being a move that pulls you towards things and another that pulls things towards you, are also useful in combat, helping with closing gaps and maintaining and prolonging combos. My main grip with the gameplay is that there is no lock-on, which makes flying enemies more difficult to deal with than necessary. I understand that this has been rectified in the PS4 release of the game, but the PC version hasn't been updated to reflect this.

Boss fights are stylish, but almost brain dead easy, as much like the other enemies, attacks are telegraphed far in advance and seem to have a generous window in which they can be dodged. Bosses also have quite obvious weakpoints and definitely feel more "video gamey" than previous or future entries would. That said, the design of the bosses is fantastic and I had a lot of fun fighting a Bill O'Reily espy who appears as a giant VR head. 

Level design is interesting and varied, but as mentioned before, gets bogged down through being overlong and just being backed with grappling points pits and all of that. The collectibles and secret missions have been significantly pared down compared to other entries. Red orbs are now a currency to buy consumables, much like in DMC4, but upgrades are now essentially bought by 'levelling up' from collecting enough white orbs dropped by enemies in combat. I thought this system worked well and incentivises stylish play as more orbs drop in relation to your stylish rank. Red orbs do seem few and far between, but the lower prices compared to the other titles does reflect this. Green orbs are present, but are actually very rare and never dropped by enemies, making mid-level healing something thats especially difficult without using consumable items or rinsing Devil Trigger. 

The story is fairly well done and gives a more grounded version of Dante. I know a lot of fans werent a fan with the edgy, more youthful aspects of the character, but he works well and this serves well as an origin story. By time the credits roll, this version of Dante isn't so far removed from the mainline games' portrayal. The writing is solid and cribbing from movies such as "They Live" and investing the DMC story more in relatable urban enviornments instead of Gothic castles and the like, made this one feel fresh and likely informed the design team some what when it came to creating Devil May Cry V.  While this isn't the best story in gaming, its probably the most grounded and cohesive one in a Devil May Cry game and is pretty easy to follow. 

So overall, was this game a mistake by Capcom? In my opinion, no. I found Devil May Cry 4 to be slightly mid and can understand how the franchise wasn't really appealing to a large audience. The game reviewed well at the time despite negative fan reaction and gamers who played it for what it was found an enjoyable experience. Unfortunately, the climate at the time meant that single player titles weren't as in fashion anymore and a lot of the series existing fanbase had turned against Capcom without really giving this game a fair shake. 

So to sum it up, while I'm glad the mainline DMC games returned with V, I feel like DmC was a great attempt at a reboot and part of me wishes we could have seen what was next for this slightly edgier, but deeper version of Dante. If you haven't played this before but like the idea of the character action genre, this is a great entry point. If you bypassed this out of some misplaced sense of betrayal from Capcom, give this a try, it might surprise you.

132317735.review:
[h1]TLDR: This is DMC Focus Group Edition. Notorious for being the exact opposite of what fans expected after DMC4, it’s a huge let-down while also being a competent game. It lacks complexity in its combat, the writing is bad and most characters are infuriating - especially Dante - all in the name of "making DMC more accessible". It’s not a bad game in and of itself though, and would’ve been better off without the DMC license attached to it. Recommended if on sale, but keep in mind this isn't the typical DMC formula.[/h1]

DmC is one for the history books. A word about its development is required for context: Capcom wanted a more accessible DMC title and Ninja Theory, a studio with some chops in character-action games (and more recently of Hellblade fame) would be hired for the job. NT really wanted to stay faithful to the originals, but Capcom kept pushing back against that. Fans didn’t take the new direction well at all (understandably so) and NT took the blunt of the criticism - something they would in turn handle in the worst possible manner. The internet doesn't forget.  

The game came out and it "didn’t find its audience" - because said audience only ever existed in Capcom’s focus groups, if at all. Nobody wanted a toned-down combat system that’s admittedly pretty good, well animated and very stylish but way too easy for veterans and probably too hard for newcomers at the same time. The story and general vibe that reeks of early-2010’s emo edginess along with terrible writing sealed the deal: as a DMC game, it was dead on arrival. Oh and Dante? He’s annoying. [i]Really, really annoying[/i]. 

In hindsight though, the game is alright and it feels good. Animations, effects, graphics and sounds are all pretty darn good and the OST is a banger featuring Combichrist and Noisia.
The combat system is basically a streamlined version of DMC3 & 4’s. I’m not good at DMC - in fact DMC3 in normal mode is still a real challenge to me - but I did manage to S rank all missions in Hard (SOS) mode. It was a good challenge and felt really good to play overall. 
What I’m getting at is that it has just enough depth to require some mastery and practice, ultimately giving you that feeling of having improved as a player but not enough to satisfy the combo junkies and I totally understand how lacking this must feel to them.

One thing to note is that this PC version is a really good port, but it’s the original release. A "Definitive Edition" was later released on 8th gen consoles with a bevy of gameplay tweaks, making for a better experience overall. There are mods to replicate some of those improvements, but not all of them sadly. Needless to say, the Definitive Edition wasn’t released on PC and most likely never will be. 

It’s often on sale and in all honesty you’ll most likely have a decent time with this game. However, if you’re a die-hard, air-dash-cancelling-backroll-trickster combo junkie, then this isn’t a game made for you and I really, really empathize with you: Capcom did you dirty on this one. 

Recommended if on sale, with the DLCs – hard pass if you’re any good at character-action games and you’re looking for a fix. 

[spoiler]Low-key? Play this game while being drunk. It elevates the whole thing. No really, it's one of those games that's a treat with a couple beers.[/spoiler]

131854223.review:
[h1]Comentario Analítico: "DmC: Devil May Cry"[/h1]

En pleno 2013 y de la mano de Capcom y Ninja Theory se estrenó lo que fue una suerte de reboot y/o reinterpretación de una franquicia tan establecida como lo es Devil May Cry, meramente titulado como "DmC: Devil May Cry" y al que no le fue muy bien en ventas ni en críticas.

Defiendo a este título como un excelente juego de acción cuya mala reputación nace de lo ocurrido previo y posterior a su estreno, con desarrolladores insultando tanto a los fanáticos como a los títulos de antaño; Es natural que se repudie y cuestione esta actitud, pero nada de esto debe perjudicar a la valoración final del producto.

No obstante existe varios aspectos muy críticados de este título que sí tienen cabida en esta reseña, hablo de la simplificación del combate y la estupidización del humor, además de algún que otro detalle como haber estado capado a 30 fps' en su fecha de lanzamiento.

[list]
    [*]Es cierto que el humor y los diálogos por momentos carecen del carisma natural de antaño, pero creo en su mayoría que esta percepción negativa hacia este Dante nace de su actitud inmadura y a la comparación con aquél que ya tuvo tiempo para crecer y desarrollarse en los juegos anteriores.

Este Dante no es un mal personaje, sólo es un personaje distinto.

    [*]Con respecto a la jugabilidad, el movimiento y particularmente las plataformas son muy superiores a la de juegos previos, en parte gracias a la desaparición de la cámara libre pero sin obviar la fluidez de los controles y el combate, que es muy simplón en comparación a la complejidad que se adoptó a partir de Devil May Cry 3.

Claramente es un juego más orientado al público casual y eso es algo que siempre generó rechazo, más en su época de estreno; en lo personal no creo que sea algo negativo, sino algo simplemente distinto. Está genial que haya tanto juegos con un techo alto para la habilidad, y otros más permisivos para jugadores casuales, siempre y cuando en el proceso esta simplificación no perjudique otros aspectos tales como la acción, que acá no ocurre.

Los combates en este juego son geniales, opino que su mayor pecado está en la camara, que aporta valor al plataformeo pero perjudica la visibilidad en el combate, que cuando funciona resulta sumamente gratificante aunque fracase en ofrecer jefes imaginativos (Salvando a Bob Barbas, que fue mi favorito).
[/list] 

A todo esto se suma una escena de Vergil que escandalizó a varios, aunque en lo personal creo que esto último sólo son quejas de gente de berrinche fácil.

Para finalizar, quiero destacar rápidamente la brillante selección musical de este juego, en particular los tracks del álbum "No Redemption" de Combichrist de los que se destacan "Throat Full of Glass" y "Never Surrender".

[b]¿En conclusión?[/b] Un muy buen Hack and Slash.

This game was unjustly underrated and is actually a gem that deserves better.

The plot was surprisingly very bold in that you live in a world secretly controlled by demons via their proxies of politicians, celebrities and unhealthy junk food, and you help out a group dedicated to exposing the conspiracy to anyone who is willing to open their eyes.
The gameplay is stellar as well, combat feels smooth and you are given a variety of toys to use such as the standard sword, pistols, angel and demon weapons plus more as you make progress, and each weapon can be given upgrades to make you even more formidable in later levels.

The part i loved most about the story is how well done the boss fights are, especially vs Bob Barbas, whoever designed that entire sequence deserved a raise for how thoughtfully executed it was.
Secondly we have the DLC content, one of which is an infinite arena where you fight stronger waves for leaderboard points, very self explanatory. You also get a story set after the events of the main game, with a unique playstyle and short but sweet story that'll make you want all the power for yourself.

In the end this is definitely a game i recommend, it was controversial for its time but you literally cannot ignore that banger of a soundtrack, or the banter between the brothers that compliment each others personalities, ignore all the criticism and try out this game asap before you lose out on the essential demon hunting experience

131636917.review:
Dante is now a foul-mouthed, meth addict edge lord (Donte) and must take down the CEO of Evil: Mundus aka demonhitler. With the help of the squirrel-semen witch and fedora-tipping Vergil (yes), they set off to fight a soft drink company, fake news, and a giant demon fetus. 

Safe to say it was a questionable way to reboot Devil May Cry, and deserves to be laughed at in perpetuity. I would probably take a lukewarm dump on this game if the franchise ended with it, but thankfully DMC 5 exists, so now DmC: Devil May Cry can be judged on its own merits:

Fun gameplay and some half decent enemy design in a game with the most cringeworthy dialogue you can come by (the cringe being a plus in my book). To elaborate on the combat mechanics: Fake Dante's moveset is a dumbed-down version of Dante's and Nero's moveset in DMC 4. No more Style Switching, or Styles at all for that matter. However, there is still some depth to it with the now instant weapon switching, and the utility of dead angles using free aim. Its far from braindead and does the job for the 7 hour game it is, and is definitely more complex than DMC 1 & 2.
Some boredom was had in the latter part of the game, but whenever you are not enjoying yourself with the combat or level design, you can always find infinite entertainment in the god awful "hello fellow kids" story and writing. 6/10 would reboot again.

And opening new skills one by one is making your fight more different and interesting. 

So let me summarize, it is worth playing. Just buy the game and enjoy the gameplay.
By the way, there is a good reason to play this game, it is; you don't have to play other games, before that. It has a separate origin story from the main origin and it gives you all details which you should know.

131532198.review:
I finished both of the campaign's (didn't get all the collectibles, achievements and whatnot though), and despite the fact that sometimes it gets a little wack and crude, it is quite fun overall. A few things I really liked from this game include:

1) Upgrade Points - Like the ATLA game for the GameCube, instead of spending red orbs to buy new skills like in any other DMC game, you instead earn white orbs based on performance throughout the game. You can freely spend and re-organize the points however you want to so if you know you won't be using a particular weapon or technique all that much, you can spec it into something else you do want. 

2) Trigger Swap - Maybe I'm wrong about this but I don't think the triggers are used all that much in most other DMC games. Here it's more relevant and works pretty well. 

Though personally, I wish there were more opportunities to cancel out of attacks and into a dodge. I get it for the heavy demonic weapons that they should be slow and heavy, but for all forms of attack I personally found myself getting hit quite a bit because I began an attack and couldn't cancel out of it in time to dodge a big attack. 

7/10 - I get people may harp on the story and overuse of profanity but ignoring that it's overall a pretty fun action game with interesting ideas that I wished stuck around for more action games.

131425689.review:
Este juego fue subestimado injustamente y en realidad es una joya que merece algo mejor.

La trama fue sorprendentemente audaz en el sentido de que vives en un mundo controlado en secreto por demonios a través de sus representantes de políticos, celebridades y comida chatarra poco saludable, y ayudas a un grupo dedicado a exponer la conspiración a cualquiera que esté dispuesto a abrir los ojos.
La jugabilidad también es estelar, el combate se siente fluido y se le da una variedad de juguetes para usar, como la espada estándar, pistolas, armas de ángel y demonio, y más a medida que avanza, y cada arma se puede actualizar para que incluso más formidable en niveles posteriores.

La parte que más me gustó de la historia es lo bien hechas que están las peleas de los jefes, especialmente contra Bob Barbas, quien haya diseñado toda la secuencia merecía un aumento por lo bien que la ejecutó.
En segundo lugar, tenemos el contenido DLC, uno de los cuales es una arena infinita en la que luchas contra olas más fuertes para obtener puntos en la tabla de clasificación, lo cual se explica por sí mismo. También obtienes una historia ambientada después de los eventos del juego principal, con un estilo de juego único y una historia corta pero dulce que te hará querer todo el poder para ti.

Al final, este es definitivamente un juego que recomiendo, fue controvertido para su época, pero literalmente no puedes ignorar esa banda sonora, o las bromas entre los hermanos que complementan las personalidades de los demás, ignora todas las críticas y prueba este juego lo antes posible. antes de perder la experiencia esencial de cazar demonios

I recently played DMC Devil May Cry and I have to say, it exceeded my expectations. The combat system is incredibly satisfying and fluid, allowing me to seamlessly switch between melee and ranged weapons while pulling off stylish combos. The "Stylish Rank" system added an extra layer of fun, as I was constantly trying to improve my rank by performing more varied and stylish attacks.

The story was also well-written and kept me invested throughout the game. The characters were well-developed and the plot was engaging, making me want to know more about the game's world. The visuals and sound design were also top-notch. The environments were detailed and the soundtrack added to the game's overall atmosphere.

Overall, I highly recommend DMC Devil May Cry to fans of the action-adventure genre. It offers a fresh take on the Devil May Cry franchise and is a must-play for anyone looking for a thrilling and satisfying gaming experience.

130833696.review:
If this game didn't hold the DMC name and was called literally anything else, even something as silly as "El Donte's Adventure In Limbo" it would have been a classic that is still talked about to this very day. The gameplay is just PERFECT. The music is awesome, with one of the best OSTs I have heard in a video game.
Compared to hack and slash games that were released in 2013, like MGR: R this game is MILES better in terms of gameplay. (as much as I LOVE MGR)
So, what went wrong? The game had no character, no confidence in itself, unlike MGR.

The problem is, it tried to reboot DMC into a direction that fans of the series didn't like, so it was bound to fail.
And the developers were frustrated with how the fans were getting mad about "small" changes such as Dante's new hair colour (which is understandable to be frustrated about, imagine working on a game for a long time only for it to be hated because of a hair colour change, a change that was forced by Capcom, but at the same time, the fans are also right since the white/silver hair is one of Dante's defining features that the reboot Dante feels like a different character, which he kind of is) that they tried to make fun of the older games in their presentations, interviews and in the game. This didn't help their game sell on release, obviously.

The [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OgfXeUldLt4] trailer [/url] also showed a completely different game, one with a much darker tone that looked very, very cool. Too bad they had to change it after the reveal due to fan reactions.

This game had an unfortunate development. Capcom forced the devs to change everything about the game to distance themselves from the older games as possible, to give it a more "Western" feel. This was common at the time, as Capcom kept sourcing out games to be made by western devs, and wanted the games to feel "Western". This included changing Dante's design. The [url=https://www.reddit.com/r/DevilMayCry/comments/9bwa6m/early_dmc_dante_designs_were_more_faithful_to_the/] original concept. [/url]
Capcom wanted the remake to be as different from the original DMC as possible, which hurt Ninja Theory and the game a lot. Then after the reveal trailer they had to change a lot of elements in the game due to the massive backlash that they got from the fans.
One has to wander, what was their original vision like if Capcom didn't force changes? Or even how the game would have turned out if they stuck to what was shown in the ad?

Is the gameplay is better than DMC 3/4/5? No.
Is is better than every other hack and slash game in terms of gameplay? To me? Absolutely. Every game I have ever played were you control a third person character and had combat in it paled in comparison to DmC in terms of gameplay. (Besides the mentioned games.)

Oh well. At least Itsuno loved it, and wanted a sequel to be made for DmC. And DmC has also inspired a lot of things in DMC V. ( 
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/ArmagdoGaming/recommended/601150/] Refer to my DMC V review for more info on that [/url])

TL;DR get this game, forget that it has the DMC name, and you'll love it.
