130002821.review:
Honestly this game gets too much flak for deviating from the aesthetic and certain systems of the original game, but it still is a great game in its own right. If they put in styles, and had a style switcher, I think this game would be just as well-liked as the others. If nothing else it doesn't suffer from the horrible camera problems most of the other games do (with the exception of DMC5), and you are also imbued with two alternate weapons pretty early so you can actually enjoy making unique combos from an early point.

Something everyone hated, and that they rectified in the Definitive Edition on consoles (that you can still mod out on PC), is the color-coded enemies which are only vulnerable to one type of weapon (Angel/Demon respectively). This completely takes out 2/3 of your arsenal which defeats the purpose of the game. Fortunately as I mentioned you can mod them such that they are vulnerable to all weapons... I highly encourage you do this as fighting these enemies is a massive damper on the experience otherwise.

The boss fights don't much compare to that of the mainline series, but the enemies are generally fun to fight and not frustrating either; I feel some enemies in DMC3/4 were straight up designed to be annoying first rather than challenging. Conversely the enemy designs are tough when they need to be but still fair.

Even after all these, DmC was a good time. Pick this up if you see this on sale.

Dmc the reboot, is a fun and enjoyable game in quite a lot of aspects. (But also suffered some wrong decisions in it's development) The gameplay honestly shows how the combat has become a foundation and has been improved for DMC V, but also has it's fair share of great combat for the series.

Sadly the story and characters are not the best in the series. That is why I recommend to not compare the story to the other games so you can better enjoy it. But despite that flaw it's still a great game for the devs who's not familiar with this type of game.

Pros:
-Best grapple in the series
-You have a lot of weapons and combos
-New player friendly style system (easy to maintain)
-character development at the end

Cons:
-Color coded enemies (can be modded out)
-Bloody palace timer  (can be modded out)
-bullet rain is too slow  (can be modded out)
-DT throws everyone on air  (can be modded out, but don't use the mod on the last fight)
-Dialog and story is quite bad (especially if you're a DMC fan)
-unlikable characters (yep not a single one)

All in all, it;s still a great game (modded), but for playing vanilla on pc... It might not be the best.

129220391.review:
Holy crap this was amazing. I went in expecting a crappy reboot, and instead got one of the best DMC games there is. This was more fun than 5 for me, especially because of the focus on just Dante and not 2 other guys as well. To put it simply, there was nothing I hated. Music? Bangers. Gameplay? Flowing. Environments? Unique to say the least. This game doesn't have you switching weapons, rather you hold down left or right trigger to switch to an angelic or demonic weapon. Each specified for a specific style of combat. This leads to some of the most fluid and simply fun weapon switching I have had in the series. The game was rough, but didn't want me to suffer, and was a solid but easy enough challenge throughout. I love the metal soundtrack that accompanies the demon busting, and the environments. Beyond a chefs kiss. These were more than just "Guys look it's kinda hell" they were amazing demonic corruptions of seemingly normal places, and other times it was gothic madness. I can't say anything in specific, but trust me. It is great. The story was something I heard many gripes about, but I loved it. Campy, Edgy, Way-To-Serious goodness that I love. Something as simple as Dante telling a boss to F off is hilarious to me.

Overall, Amazing. Better than 5 because of it's focus on Dante in my book. Solid 9.5/10

128704627.review:
I went in with VERY low expectations, but this actually turned out to be really good. I do actually like this game better than DMC1. Of course, the new version of Dante is completely different to the original, but honestly, he has his own charm. Not nearly as likeable or cocky as the original, and he is definitely more seriosu and immature, but I found myself genuinely laughing at some of his lines.
The level design is genuinely amazing. It all looks so beautiful and I could look at the landscapes for hours. There are also so many ideas that you would never find in the main series, like fighting a news reporter in a news station, or even a demonic night club. The gameplay is amazing as well, and I genuinely had more fun with it than the original DMC1.
The story is also surprisingly good. I feel like they wanted to make a DMC game, but they had so many new ideas and concepts that went against the established rules of the DMC universe, so they decided to make a reboot, and I'm genuinely not complaining.
They honestly could have changed all of the names and tweaked the story a slight bit and they could have had a completely original franchise, but I'm glad we got what we got, and I actually would not mind seeing a sequel.
Overall, very underrated, and I highly recommend it.
8.8/10

127126038.review:
Every mechanical / design change Ninja Theory made to the franchise was a massive improvement. 

1. They replaced the obnoxious 90s Capcom castle backtracing across a needlessly large map with uni-directional levels
2. Although the levels are easier to progress through, Ninja Theory replaced grading level performance based on orb collection with grading based on discoverable souls/keys to encourage exploration and secret-finding for each mission
3. DmC replaces the need to manually equip melee weapons with using 3 different melee weapons using no trigger, LT, and RT. More interesting / seamless combos.
4. Instead of needing to use a multi-button combo for dodge (why was that ever a thing), they've assigned dodge to RB
5. Ninja Theory dropped the unnecessary upgrade currency and variable cost of abilities of previous games with straight-forward upgrade points, and generously give you several moves for each weapon from the jump so you can... have fun with the game.
6. They improved the design of Nero's grab by allowing you to pull in or pull towards every enemy in the game, instead of being able to do just one or the other in DMC4. 
7. The "puzzles" of the DmC franchise are done away with entirely (e.g., activating and pushing a statue towards a pedestal)
8. The secret missions are much less sweaty/obnoxious to play through
9. The auto-lock on camera is surprisingly intuitive, and the camera during action is less intrusive than previous games
10. The move set in general, across all three melee weapons, feels more expansive and intuitive to use than previous games
11. The crappy platforming in previous DMC entries, where if you mess up you have a mandatory arena fight for 2 minutes, is thankfully dropped in DmC.

The game feels great to play, the big block text in levels + collapsing environments of purgatory class up the joint, and the soundtrack is the least-bad of all DMC games thus far.  Good game overall.

124766065.review:
Alright, this was my first Devil May Cry game, and I only realized later that it wasn't exactly "representative", being from a different team and all. That said, I had a blast with my 9 hours with DMC.

Combat: Just a ton of fun. I opted to try to play with mouse and keyboard (just to see if it were even possible), and enjoyed it just fine (with only a few combos requiring minor finger stretching).
Enemies: A good amount of variety, predictable but not overly idiotic AI.  Good design.
Environments: Unique, nightmarish, grotesquely gorgeous.  Love the use of visual text to accentuate the demonic threats you're hearing. 
Cut scenes: I can't remember the last time I enjoyed the cut scenes in a game more.  Animations, models, dialog and voice acting are all on-point - which is good because the overall story isn't really all that.
Difficulty: I played on Human (easy) and felt the challenge was just about right. Most of my deaths were caused by falling on the stretches of platforming.
Music: Perfect mix of dark ambient and digi-rock/industrial bangers.  A great OST.

Verdict: It's a great game that I'd have no trouble recommending to almost anyone, especially if it's on sale. Well done, Ninja Theory. And now I'm looking forward to playing the "real" Devil May Cry games...

124733933.review: The combat of the game is very basic compared to dmc 3, but this is a gorgeous eye candy game, its a shame the drama around the game eclipsed its true potential and charm.

124640719.review:
Just on the offset I don't think Devil May Cry as a whole is my series, I beat 1 3 4 and 5, 4 and 5 after beating this one. I'm largely going to review this as its own standalone thing, because it's a different dev and a different universe. Though obviously I have to compare and contrast for context and gameplay.

The game on the offset is a lot easier and none of the timings are difficult to grasp. The enemies all have gimmicks that require timed attacks or specific moves to take down but their cycles are slower and their attack patterns are more obvious, making it a lot easier to play and feel competent. The rating system is also really forgiving but if I remember DMC4 was also kind of like that. I don't think this is necessarily a negative for casual play it just means you aren't gonna be hitting a training mode to get down timings to just fight regular enemies, though you may have to exploit that in the difficulties where the enemies are more plentiful and move faster.

The primary gimmick is that you're the child of an angel and a demon (instead of a human and a demon) so you can choose between your angelic powers and your demonic powers. they're locked to keys you hold down while you perform the actions, and I think it's a fairly straight forward system that's easy to grasp. I would say as a whole there's a lot more platforming but I think that's a good way to actually train up the grappling mechanics for combat and provides a little more variety than just being shoehorned into arenas.

The plot is a plot. As a whole I don't like the plots of any of these games. This one is consistently not good but the performances are fine which make it more tolerable. It's also standalone and they don't try to create an overly complicated deeplore around it (to its credit, DMCV  handled its lore burden pretty well)  I think most of the plot is stupid and, paradoxically, I think Dante is the best part. There are a ton of scenes I saw beforehand I thought were just clever edits or youtube poops but no, they're really just absurd in context too. He's kind of something closer to Nero being an obnoxious punk ass kid more than a suave bounty hunter. Nero is probably my favourite character from the main series which might be why I didn't mind this as much as other people did. 

One weird thing about the plot is Vergil seems a lot more... defined? I didn't play 3 special edition so Vergil was introduced as a big bad in a tower and that was basically his full context for me in the original series. Now he's a very dated-even-when-this-came-out capital A Anonymous hacker that bonds with Dante over the story and eventually goes off the deep end. I actually think it kind of works structurally and gave me more of an emotional impact by the time I got to the fight rather than suddenly introducing him in the third game. I don't necessarily like Vergil in either series but I think this one wins by a hair, if only because his famous line "I've got a bigger dick"

Graphically I think the game is great for the target system. Really solid use of colour palettes. Most of the actual environments are kind of that "floating brick vaguely european town" otherworld vortex thing that virtually every game of this era was designed around, but it does break out of it enough that it doesn't get grating. It also had the advantage of coming out much later in the console life cycle than 4 did, which I think shows its age a lot more and also had a notoriously bad PC port. This game ran really solid even on my old gtx560m laptop at the time. 

Also the soundtrack is good. Noisia and Combichrist aren't artists I listen to in my off time but I think the work both of them did in this is superb and is the one thing about this game that fits the brand. Noisia handled a lot of the environmental music while Combichrist did basically every action theme and, no complaints. 

This game is regularly cheap, and worth a pick up if A) you're just curious how dumb the game can be or B) the main series is a little above your punching weight. I think difficulty wise it lies somewhere closer to Bayonetta where the challenge is there if you insist but it isn't going to shame you if you don't want to sit around learning combos instead of playing a video game.

124609637.review:
This is a game that raises a lot of questions. This is a game that shouldn't exist. Aside from profit, what was their goal here? Reboot the franchise? Retell the story? Did Ninja Theory think they could do a better job with Devil may Cry?
     This is the video game equivalent of trying to paint an orange purple and calling it a giant grape. It's essentially Ninja Gaiden with a Devil may Cry plot and skin. 

     In the end, what do I think? Does it play well? Yes. Is it fun? Yes. Is it a good game in it's own right? Yes. Is it worth buying? No. Does it stand up to it's counterpart? Not in the least. Is it visually fluid and impressive? Definitely. Is it well made? Yes. I guess if you were new to Devil may Cry this would be an odd way to introduce yourself to the series. Do you need to see this train wreck? Yes. *rubs temples* Just play the original games instead.

         Does it need to exist? No.

122449519.review:
So for some reason people hate on this game for only these 3 reasons: edginess, character redesign, and Dante as a whole. People who dislike this game just for those reasons don't take the time to realize the good parts about it. For example, some things this game did that was great was being better than dmc 2, having the best noncombat gameplay in the series by far, having a cool soundtrack, and trying something new. Trying something new can result to being awful, bad, good, or amazing. So obviously a lot of people don't like the choices made for this game, but its not all bad. Combat was as expected, and story was mediocre.

The bosses in this game though are pretty much all the same. They are all mini game bosses and its all the same thing, dodge stuff, shoot stuff, then you get a few seconds to attack the only place where they take damage. Nothing special here.

The weapons though in this game have a twist to them. There are angel weapons which are fast but deal low damage, mainly used to move around the enemies. There are demon weapons which are slow but hard hitting and can punch through shields. I think this is a pretty cool and welcome edition to this game. However, there is this really annoying mechanic where with some enemies are color coded. You can only damage red enemies with demon weapons and you can only damage blue enemies with angel weapons. And many times throughout the campaign, there will be these really annoying parts where they put both red and blue enemies in the same place and those parts can get extremely irritating especially since their attacks are unique and they can work together to make you die. For example, a blue enemy can freeze you for a few seconds and a red enemy can make the ground around them lava and can burn and hurt you. Put these together, and you have a few seconds where you are frozen while standing on lava and repeatedly taking damage.

Even with a fair bit of negatives, this game can still be really enjoyable. Don't be afraid to try it out, its fun!

122133163.review:
I know many people look at the number on the review and say: 6?! Really? Without getting into the review. Listen, I loved playing Devil May Cry; but there were too many things I didn't love about it. After playing through the game once I can safely say: "I'm glad I played it, but I'll never play this again."

Also to note is my relative inexperience with prior games. I have played  DMC games in the past, but never religiously.

The Good
There plenty to love about DmC. The first of which is Dante. Walking through a fun house during the first level, a deranged doll springs into Dante's face. The moment is meant to scare the gamer, but Dante simply exclaims "whatever" and keeps walking. I laughed out loud. The writing for the game is great and it comes out in little moments like this.

The music and level design in the game are like PB&J. Nothing is better than taking a group of enemies head-on while some headbanger metal plays in a disco night-club from Hell. Levels were never confusing or unfair. When blended with the kinetic music it's tough not to get into the demon killing spirit. Or the 'killing a giant demon baby' spirit.


The graphics are amazing. The game looks very pretty with no noticable texture issues or anything.

The Bad
I understand the original games were episodic. The break up of the 20 episodes was so jarring it actually pulled me out of the game. A good example is when you meet a demon and must retrieve his eye. You know immediately that an entire level will be devoted to this task after you meet him. After that level the story continues. It makes you go "Yep. Side quests that are main quests." It took me out of the story when all I wanted to do was simply continue on with more missions.

Higher scores require speed and variety. Although the majority of the weapons are fun, you will pick favorites and use them more than the others. I found the Arbitor, Aquila and Ebony and Ivory to be my trinity of weapons. I also found it difficult to force myself to use something like Kablooey when I didn't want to.

There are hidden keys and such scattered across all the levels that force you to play through the game once to unlock all the abilities and weapons, then return to prior levels in order to retrieve them. It's tough to explore a level or try platforming to reach a key I see, when it's not possible to retrieve until I unlock a specific weapon 5 levels later. This game relies on repeat playthroughs to find all the keys and I just didn't love it enough to replay just for collectibles.

Also Witches. Those awful stupid witches.

Borrow or Rent it
DmC is basically an in-between. The creators wanted a game the revitalized the Devil May Cry franchise by creating a new audience while trying not to alienate its original fanbase. If it could have picked one direction or the other I think the overall flow of the game would've been better. This game was stuck in the middle.

Despite its flaws, it's a must-play. I wouldn't buy it or anything but find a friend's and borrow it for the weekend.

I am a fan of super cheesy acting with corny dialogue. It's so stupid to where it loops around to being good.

Anyway, the gameplay is great, weapon variety and combos are there.  The music absolutely slaps and there's a LOT of it, you'll get a new track to jam out while killing demons in nearly every stage. The bosses are a little on the "meh" side though, with maybe 3 of them I really liked. The only bad thing about combat is the color coded enemies, in a game where you are to dish out combos in the most stylish way possible gets completely contradicted when the weapons you are allowed to use gets heavily restricted, I hear the Definitive Edition (which is only available on consoles, thanks Capcom.) doesn't have this issue and even has a camera lock on.

As far as story goes, I will say it was actually nice to see Dante and Vergil actually act and bond like brothers. Hell having Vergil as your ally at first only to turn at the end as an enemy was neat for a change. That's kind of all I have good to say about it, unless you're a fan of said cheesy acting and corny dialogue like I am, you won't have much enjoyment out of it.

In the end, Ninja Theory gets my vote. Give me a sequel.

120950716.review:
First things first: I must say, I have never played a DMC game.

Now we are done with this statement, I have to say I had fun. The game is sometimes a bit too gross; the story is kind of cliche. Dante evolves throughout the story, so I suppose I can say he is improving (I can't take Kat seriously, she is just a teen eyecandy I guess) and I feel this whole Vergil line was pretty rushed and odd at the end. It felt so out of the blue.

I probably could have not finished the game if the gameplay hadn't been enjoyable, but it is! Now I won't complain about the camera and the enemy lock because I read this is fixed on consoles. Yes, not seeing who you are attacking was a big problem for a while. After a that, I guess you can get used to it. The music was a "blurry metal mishmash" but fit the theme.

So far, this doesn't sound exciting, I know. But overall, it somehow works! After I finally found my favourite weapons, my best strategy for how to avoid enemies and how to worry less because of the camera problem, the gameplay carries the game. The majority of the levels are cool, (the Disco level was such an attack on my eyes, but that is the most memorable one.) they tried to play with this limbo idea. There is a ton of art that you can unlock by playing the game for collectionists. (The alternative Kat designs were better, just saying)

One more thing: This Dante is edgy as heck. I did laugh at some of the things he said, and you know what? This game is like the end of the 90's or early 2000's bad action movies. It is kind of a stupid story, with neat action, all for show, but overall it is a guilty pleasure!

Recommended! (At a discount, the price tag is too high.)

However, the Vergil DLC is NOT recommended. It doesn't add anything new to the story aside from showing he is being crazy. Even worse, the cutscenes are just quickly drawn pictures, not even cinematic like in the main game. That one is skippable.

119842919.review:
Much better than it's given credit for. While the reinterpretation of the series' main characters was far from ideal, and the story was somewhat lacklustre, the DmC reboot really doesn't deserve as much hate as it gets from fans of the older games. Gameplay-wise, after having played through most of the DMC series, this entry honestly is almost on par with DMC5. Combat is smooth and the weapon variety is solid, and the only real downside to the gameplay is the sheer number of enemies that require you to use certain weapon affinities or have far too much hyper-armour, especially on higher difficulties.

The game also has solid art direction - while certain enemy and character designs leave something to be desired, the level design, colour grading and Devil Trigger effects are all visually interesting throughout.

The reimagined Dante takes a while to get used to, but he isn't THAT bad. Vergil, however, underwent a full character assassination, which understandably puts a lot of people off. Regardless, if you can look past the story (which DMC was never really the strongest for anyway), you'll find a vastly underappreciated combat system and a generally fun time.

119791228.review:
I have gone out of my way to try and treat this game as its own thing. The game regularly tried to fight me on this, making regular references to other DMC games that add nothing but comparisons to something better. And yet, even giving this game enough benefit of the doubt to make you weep, this game is just... not very good.
I'll start with the good; the visual design of the levels are often gorgeous, even while the actual level layouts are poor to mediocre. Limbo looks genuinely cool, there are some interesting setpieces, even when it's trying too hard by having blueprints for a heist appear over the level it's at least a nice idea. The highlight of the game are a scene where pizza covers Dante's dick, and the first few bosses, specifically the foul-mouthed succubus (who talks like a self-parody and is one of the only non-sexy succubi I've seen in media), and the Falcon News boss (who has aged like a fine wine). And sometimes, traversing environments with the grappling hooks and aerial movement can be fun.

And that is where me being nice ends.

The gameplay is... above average. It's better than most generic PS3 generic action games, but considering that's the core selling point it isn't really amazing. It's playable, when you aren't dealing with the more annoying enemies, and fortunately the combo meter is incredibly easy to get good scores on so not being good at it doesn't matter. I'd call it a good starting point for the series, but the plot is also repugnant. Dante is consistently a horrible, unfunny person, the plot is a mediocre "chosen one" story where another chosen one is constantly stood five feet off camera, usually not doing much until the badly-foreshadowed twist. The subject matter is often so edgy that it actually wraps back around and becomes funny, although sometimes it is just tasteless. Not even offensive, just... not adding anything of worth. I have been told it very much misses the point of the rest of the DMC series, but even in isolation it isn't a good story. It is very amusingly bad though. The game tries to take things clearly not intended to be taken seriously and then plays them completely straight, makes political commentary so laughably on-the-nose that I'm not sure they even realised it was political commentary in the first place, and gives characters no real traits, motivation, or anything to flesh them out beyond their shallow roles in the plot. It tries to reinforce the tension between the player and the main villains by regularly cutting away to them having sex or whatever they felt would be most shocking, but Dante doesn't interact with them until they're boss fights so there's no real connection beyond a vague feeling of "I should probably do revenge for my dead parents now I remember them, I guess". Even during my favourite boss fights, I could have cut out Dante and replaced him with a sexy lamp with a collection of weapons and it probably would have improved things.
But despite everything, I see potential here. The game should not be a Devil May Cry game, it shouldn't have these characters with no arcs, and they should really hire someone to make it so that I can go backwards in a level after I miss a collectable I just saw without falling through the world for some reason (I mean seriously, I can make the jump, why the hell did they remove collision? Like, I had to backtrack through that point later anyway and the collision worked then, so someone deliberately decided to fuck me I guess?).
But like... I can see something this game could be. A game where you kill demons while bad metal music plays, where the cool visual design combined with good level design, where Dante actually grew from being a dick to being nicer rather than just... getting a crush on a woman who looks like a teenager but still being a massive dick anyway? Hell, maybe a game where she's the protagonist? Or useful outside of a level which might as well have been a cutscene? 

Anyway, this Dante isn't a gay cowboy. This Dante is a closeted bisexual fuckboy who owes several people money for sexual harassment suits. This Dante would call me a slur, fatshame my baby, and then get surprised when I don't want to go on a date with him.

119591495.review:
Tiene una identidad muy clara y muy deliberada, pero esta identidad no es Devil May Cry. Cambia el par de nombres que tiene en común con DMC y esto funciona perfectamente como su propia IP. Está claro que si lo comparas a DMC3 o DMC5 por ejemplo sale perdiendo, pero prefiero ver DmC como algo aparte de los juegos numerados porque realmente no tiene prácticamente nada que ver.

119492014.review: Ultimately, I cannot recommend this game because it was the opposite of what the Devil May Cry community wanted. This reboot tries very hard to be an edgy preteen shounen or something like that (Especially considering it released in the early 2010's), and therefore forgets the identity of Devil May Cry. While the game has fluid and enjoyable combat, and so far level design appears to be good, the story and re-imagining of the characters are downright terrible. It's not even campy like the original Devil May Cry installments, its just awfully bland and dehumanising. Don't even get me started on what happened to Dante. I mean Don'te. Eh, whatever. Tl;dr good combat, awful story. I am glad that it was put to the side as only a re-imagining and we have been blessed with Devil May Cry 5. Also, this is not even the definitive edition, which did not receive a PC port. Therefore there is no lock-on feature which is essential to a good DMC experience.

118877133.review:
So I speed through both campaigns... the main campaign with dante and the additional DLC campaign with vergil... 

So here is my thoughts on the game....Lets get the negatives out of the way first.

The story is okay... you never really played DMC for the story but at least in this game they at least tried, further pushed on the levels feeling like a cinematic movie in some parts.... but I just don't like any of the characters. Dante is an unlikable dosh, he doesn't really change much at the end of the game either. Virgil is kind of a wimp through the entire campaign, he obviously can fight but no were near as strong as Dante until you get to his DLC campaign where he gains power and now is basically just the villain 2.0 Cat is just a damsel in distress most of the time, but at least she is a bit more useful than another girl from DMC 4 that we all know about.... Overall the characters are just lacking.... I didn't really like any of them. 

The combat is also pretty decent, its pretty clear that they wanted you to make you feel like a cool guy without having to reach the high skill ceilings from the other mainline DMC games so the combos feel somewhat limited even as you unlock more of them. Having Blue Weapons damage only Blue enemies and Red Weapons damaging red enemies was stupid though, it was fixed in the definitive version of the game but the PC release never got that version sadly. 

The majority of the enemies are pretty generic though, pretty uninspiring.... I like the whole limbo setting that you have to fight in but yeah the enemies could have been worked on just a bit more. 

Music is okay, not my favorite soundtrack though and nothing overly memorable. 

Boss Fights are very VERY few compared to the rest of the games.... Barley any bosses in this game, but when they do it does feel very unique and climatic. 

I'm surprised how many people liked the game though, considering the heavy backlash this game got over dantes design which is understandable he kind of sucks in the game as I mentioned before.... But it defiantly is a complete game so, no were near as bad. 

I recommend it in the end though, obviously not my favorite DMC game but I think its better than DMC 2 and maybe even DMC 1 just a bit.... Would I want a sequel to this game? Ehhh it depends on how they handle the story and if dante has any development... maybe change that boring devil trigger they have too but yeah its not a bad game as I said.... worth playing at least one time.

118709248.review:
It's hard to recommend this version since it lacks the gameplay tweaks of the "definitive edition" which is only available on consoles. The DLC must also be purchased separately, so no playable Vergil unless you want to pay extra. 

Still, this version goes pretty cheap so if you have no prospect of obtaining the other one I would say it's worth considering giving it some time. The game definitely falls short of the heights of the others in the series, but it's pretty fun for what it is, despite some problems.

In terms of the combat mechanics: the depth doesn't come close to something like DMC5, but Dante has a decently varied moveset which is easy to deploy and fun to explore. Tearing through demons is satisfying and cool, so I'd say on that basic level it's successful.  The main drawbacks come from enemy designs, with the worst moments coming from multiple enemies spamming hyper armoured attacks constantly, and colour-coded enemies that prevent you using your full arsenal. Of course you can learn to play around these quirks, but it feels like the game is working against itself sometimes. Boss fights are also few in number and generally uninteresting to fight. 

Non-combat mechanics are really tertiary in a game like this, but it's probably worth mentioning that the story and characters are something you will either love or hate. Or both. There are also traversal mechanics which offer some basic jumping puzzles between fights and hidden paths that lead to secret missions. Personally I found the pacing much better in repeat playthroughs when I was able to skip cutscenes, ignore alternate routes I'd already explored, and get straight to the action. But if you appreciate the adventure/exploration side of games like this then I think you'll probably find something to like here.

The last thing I want to mention is the level design. You spend most of your time in a sort of demonic corruption of the real world called "limbo" - the upshot of which is that the environments change around you a lot and you spend considerable amounts of time on platforms suspended in a void. This is actually quite welcome because it gives you the option of throwing enemies to their death in some circumstances, and the positioning of bottomless pits makes fight arenas varied. The aesthetic of racing through a reality that is hostile to your presence is also petty cool, though it sacrifices the sense of place you might otherwise hope to get while exploring. 

Overall this game has its fair share of flaws and contradictions, but if you can accept that about it then there's a fun experience to be had.

118296609.review:
[h1] UN REBOOT NO NECESARIO PERO UN BUEN HACK AND SLASH [/h1]

Estamos frente a un Devil May Cry que no debería tener este título, pues es un reboot que para nada se necesitaba pero eso no significa que no sea buen hack and slash.

Veo normal la mala acogida de los fans de la saga, este Dante se queda en tierra de nadie al intentar llenarlo de carisma y chulería haciendo así que sea soso, roce lo ridículo y no puedas ni tragarlo. Ahora sí, como hack and slash es un juego bastante notable pues el enlazar combos es satisfactorio y las animaciones son buenas. 

Su historia no es nada del otro mundo pero sus luchas contra los jefes son originales a más no poder y divertidas hasta tal punto que se quedan cortas. Su banda sonora un heavy metal muy cañero que hace bien el papel de meterte en las batallas.

Tiene varias cosas negativas este juego como el ser tan monocromático. Hay momentos en los que es una batalla constante hacia tu retina el tener tantos colores rojos en pantalla, luego azules y luego grises, llega un punto que es hasta mareante y te obliga a descansar para que puedas seguir jugando. Por otro lado está la cámara que se vuelve loca en muchos momentos y el apuntado de las armas es errático haciendo que pierdas combos. 

En general, si disfrutas de los hack and slash es un juego que no te dejará mal sabor de boca mientras vayas con la mentalidad de que esto no debería llamarse Devil May Cry, si vas con eso en mente, se te hará disfrutable y si por lo contrario vas pensando que te vas a encontrar con un buen juego dentro de la saga, vas a cerrarlo de inmediato e irte a la numerada. 

Mi recomendación personal es que se puede vivir sin jugar a este juego, es preferible dejarlo de lado y ahorrárselo e ir a la saga numerada ya que este juego ni es canónico ni tendrá continuación pero por lo que sé, gracias a este título cogieron buenas ideas para el quinto Devil May Cry.

Even if the story can be boring and extra edgy at times
It's all on the style and the gameplay, I legit think this is really damn good. 8,5/10

I'm happy this reboot didn't work so the series debooted back with DMC5, but still, this had so much potential. DMC3 is supposed to be Dante and Vergil's origin story, but for me that is wrong because that game only tells you about their father and that they are brothers & enemies, but it doesn't explain why Dante hunts demons, or why he and Vergil always fight to the death, if this game had just some plot points changed it could perfectly be their real origin, DMC0, a story about how Dante meet Vergil and why they are enemies, why he hunts demons and decided to make that his job, why he was so determined in defeating Mundus on DMC1.
Now this game is cannonicaly in a different timeline, but for me, changing some things on my mind, it will forever be DMC0.
If you are a hardcore DMC fan you may find this game very weird, not just because of the story and desing but also because of the gameplay (if you played DMC4 then the Angel weapon can feel like the Devil Bringer), but that doesn't mean it's bad. This at 
least deserves to be played, grab it on sale, it is a good time.

117301556.review:
This game is rad and criminally underrated. 

Pros:
+ COMBAT is really fun and engaging; being the type that I would call easy to pick up but more challenging to master (if you want to)
+ STORY is entertaining so far and quite honestly better than the original Devil May Cry from which this game is based. They story of Dante and Virgil is entertaining here, albeit a little "teen angst-y"
+ GRAPHICS are solid and the game runs really well, even on lower powered PCs. I know the game has been out for a while now, but if you're playing this in 2022, you're going to have a great time as long as your PC isn't downright ancient. 
+ STEAM DECK OPTIMIZED! If you have a Steam Deck, this is a great game to show off the console. I am running easily at 60fps

Cons:
- VOICE ACTING the voice of Dante is... a bit corny. I think the original game's tone is more goofy and over-dramatic, which I think is pretty fun, but it seems like they tried to make this Dante a little bit too "cool" and most of the time he is just cringe.
- WRITING is fine, and again, I like the story and characters overall. I just think they changed up the tone of Dante specifically from the original series and I don't love it all the time.

Overall, this is very worthy to add to your collection, especially if you can get it on sale (it's on sale for $7.49 USD as of the writing of this review) and also especially if you own a Steam Deck or just like action games similar to God of War.

117271658.review:
I was going to write something longer and more detailed, but honestly it can be summed up as: despite some cool stylistic ideas, the story was boring, the dialog was tedious, and the gameplay was monotonous/unrewarding. Don't even bother buying it unless it's on a BIG sale and you just REALLY love Hack n Slash games.

The initial "hardest" difficulty is still very easy compared to DMC 1 and 3 (especially 3). Very hack n slash, but the gameplay doesn't feel very satisfying; lots of VERY LONG animation locks that prevent dodging (enemies can literally start their wind up after you started the animation already and finish attacking you while you're still stuck in the animation), very few combos so you just end up doing the same 2 or 3 attacks over and over again. 

By mission 3 (out of like 20?) I was already skipping the cutscenes because they were so boring and uninteresting and the dialog was so cringe-y it was like nails on a chalkboard. I'm probably not going to finish the game because by mission 8/9 the game, combat, and level designs are so repetitive it's just not fun to play, not to mention the "hardest" difficulty (without completing at least 1 playthrough) provides next to no challenge at all... I also don't like the whole "mission" design over the metroidvania style... Bayonetta did all of this way better if you're looking for something more akin to the older DMC's (1 and 3 esp., but with a "mission" design instead of metroidvania)

117159581.review:
Remove Vergil. Rename Dante and recolor his coat. Make Kat the head of the resistance. Suddenly it's sufficiently different from Devil May Cry that it could have stood on its own without competing with an already great game series.

There was friction behind the scenes between Capcom and Ninja Theory, so we got this hot mess of a story.

I do love this game, having first played it when I was a teenager, and as my first game in the DMC lineup I was able to appreciate it as a dumb, edgy romp.

If you're capable of turning off the bit of your brain that rebels against calling this a DMC game, it's really fun to play.

The Devil Trigger is trash though. No excuses, no forgiveness.

117153690.review: does this game miss the point of devil may cry, yes. does this game have the worst sense of humor you've ever seen, yes. does this game, while not having bad game play, lack some replay value, yes. is this game worth playing and laughing at while enjoying a different take on dmc game play? yes. but i wouldn't feel right marking this review as positive.

117152446.review: Es el primer DMC que juego y no va a ser el último. Me ha flipado, era una saga que obviamente conocía pero que nunca me llamó la atención por su sistema de niveles, suelo disfrutar más de juegos con un punto RPG o un mundo abierto que de pie a una mayor personalización de tu experiencia, pero curiosamente esto que no me llamó la atención es lo que más he disfrutado de jugar a este juego, ya que he podido echarle desde 15 minutos sueltos cuando me apetecía hasta horas seguidas cuando he querido desbloquear logros. Lo único que había oído antes de la saga es que está hecho básicamente para molarse, ser visual y estético con tus ataques y básicamente sacarse la polla, y la verdad, es así, se nota y se disfruta cada segundo. Tienes tantas armas, ocho para ser concreto, que puedes usar simultáneamente en mitad del combate para generar combos espectaculares, moverte de aquí para allá frenéticamente, y destruir cada enemigo nuevo que se plante delante tuyo que es imposible aburrise. Además la historia está bien, los bosses son muy divertidos, aunque cuando coges rápido los patrones se hacen muy sencillos, por lo que a la vez permiten modificar la dificultad del juego en hasta 6 o 7 niveles. Los momentos de parkour son muy buenos, intuitivos y a la vez lo suficientemente complejos para que en ocasiones tengas que buscar bien para recoger el item que buscabas. El sistema de items y desbloqueables de cada nivel está muy bien, hay pocas cosas, unas almas encerradas, unas puertas y unas llaves, cuando consigues la llave correcta en la puerta correspondiente abrirás un reto externo al nivel que pueden ser desde matar unos enemigos sin repetir el mismo ataque dos veces, o hacerlo sin recibir ningún golpe, y que te darán algún objeto para mejorar características de Dante. Es un juegazo, y estoy deseando jugar la rama principal de la saga y ver las sorpresas que me deparan.

116870393.review:
The reboot of the Devil May Cry series. Top notch hack'n slash action game. While the console origins are noticeable, the porting is clean and the story, level design, and cutscenes are clearly outstanding. It is well known that the fans of the old parts are not entirely happy with the new depiction of Dante. But I actually like him better that way. But that is a matter of personal preference.

PRO's:
+ Excellent optics
+ Brutal soundtrack from death metal to disco music
+ 8 weapons with many upgrade options
+ Some really powerful weapon sounds
+ demanding boss fights
+ Large variety of opponents with different attack patterns
+ Many weapon combos that are not just decorative accessories
+ 3 basic difficulty levels and then another 4 to unlock...
+ Good English and German voice output
+ Fair autosave points
+ Useful tutorial overlays
+ Controls very well with controller and M&T
+ playing time 10-15h

116764695.review:
Its great to see DMC go to a different approach, but def not this if you were an all time fan during the 2010's. The controls take a while to get used to if you played the Capcom games, Moves such as Stinger, launching and locking on has completely changed with each controller button being something along the lines of Dantes expansive moveset. 

The skill tree is awful some moves aren't useful as some weapons are better than using than others.. It is edgy as hell kinda makes it age pretty funnier. 116228490.review:
[h1]DmC: Devil May Cry is a great game, even if different from its siblings.[/h1]

So, DmC is one of the more controversial Devil May Cry games. Reason for it being, it's a reboot. It was launched in 2013, 5 years after DMC 4, which already had mixed opinions. The game was originally planned to have a sequel, but after releasing DMC4's special edition in 2014, Capcom decided to rekindle the flame and bring the old series back with DMC 5, leaving this one to be seen as the black sheep of the family. But why is that, most reviews here are positive so what's the deal?

Well, in a word, change. DMC was already known as one of the best action series ever, with DMC 3 being loved by everyone and 4 bringing a new story with a new protagonist, that overall got a pretty positive response from the community. People already knew that Dante's arc was over from DMC 1, so the best move was to introduce new people into the mix. 5 years passed, no new game was in sight, a reboot is announced, with familiar elements but not familiar faces and a new sort of "vibe" and different gameplay mechanics. Some people liked it for what it was, and some people hated it because of what it wasn't.
Now, there are problems with it, even I have to admit it.

- Dante and Vergil are completely different people, there was potential, but the essence just wasn't there. 
- The game was launched in 2013 which was [b]the[/b] year of edgy games, so it gets kinda cringey at times. 
- Enemy color coding is a bad idea and it's very poorly executed here.

But does that hurt the experience so much it's just better not to play it?

No, absolutely fucking not, this shit rocks.

DmC takes a lot from the old games and improves on it, and although some things could've been better, there's a lot more good than bad here. The game still follows the character action, hack and slash vibe the originals had, but has a new take on some things. Gameplay is still awesome, we still hack and slash the shit out of everything, the lack of lock-on really doesn't make that much of a difference here since the game was made with that in mind, and although I wouldn't mind it coming back (which the special edition did bring, we just didn't get it), I don't miss it that much. The new weapon system is amazing, there are some flaws, but compared to DMC 3, there's a lot more "on the fly" variety. You get 5 weapons, Rebellion for base and other 4 that you unlock through the story and can switch to and from with just the press of a button. It's really intuitive and fun, specially since combos are "saved" when you switch weapons, so you can start a combo with a light weapon and finish it with a heavy one for optimized DPS. All of the weapons feel great to play with, too. They each have their use and work perfectly when used right, which is exactly what DMC is all about. Variety, fun, and style. And oh, does this game have a lot of that. As I said, the vibe of the game changed, it's a lot more apocalyptic and chaotic, the music is mostly metal (which I LOVE), the scenarios have this sort of corrupt vibe about them, like you're in a distorted world (which is actually true). 

This was actually my first Devil May Cry and I loved every second of it. I then found out about the original series, bought all of the games and played them one after another until I reached 5. Funny thing about this game is that a lot of mechanics and concepts we see in DMC 5 (the best one in the series) came from this baby right here. In DMC 5, the levels are a lot more linear, there's almost no backtracking, a lot more fighting and less parkour bits [spoiler]fucking DMC 3 and that turning cubes level[/spoiler]. Well, DmC is the same, the levels are a lot more straight forward, and even though collectibles are definetly still a thing and exploring is encouraged, everything feels natural. Even Vergil gets a gift from his alternate self, being able to summon a doppleganger just like DmC's Vergil. All of those things made DMC 5 the game it is today, and it probably wouldn't have been the same without this one.

People hate on the game because Dante isn't our wacky woohoo pizza man and Vergil looks more like a redditor than he looks half demon, but you have to understand. This game is not Devil May Cry. It may have the same name, but it's a completely different thing, with a different personality and goals. It won't grab that much of your attention with characters and sibling rivalry, but it has a ton of character to it. The faces may not be very memorable, but the combos, sounds and feelings will be. Now, I love DMC 5, it's still my favorite, I think it's the best in the series and it brings out the best in the hack-and-slash genre. But DmC still has a special place in my heart, and it has enough different mechanics for me to keep coming back to it even after playing DMC 5's campaign multiple times over.

I had tons of fun playing this fucking thing and probably will have a lot more when I play it again, and I would honestly play it over some of the originals any day, so give it a try, because I think DmC is one of the best hack and slash games out there, flawed as it may be, it's absolutely SSSensational.

115462874.review:
This game kept getting shit from really old DMC players who have grown fond of the first 3 DMC games who simply refused any change, it's honestly pathetic seeing the audience giving this much shit to a good game.

DmC is a great game if you want action, and most importantly hack and slash. DMC fanbase loves to shit on Dark Souls for being "unstylish" and "hard", but also hate this game for being "easier" (almost like higher difficulty doesn't exist here) and for it being more stylish for less skill. 

This game has clean combos, balanced enemies, good bosses, a difficulty for everyone, great level design, graphics, sound FX.

The story is kind of mediocre but it can be catchy if you're the right player, and to be fair this franchise really doesn't focus on story, ever since the first game the story has been a secondary attraction.

I'd recommend getting this game on sale like I got it, it's a fun game and it's worth playing even now. Very addicting and well made.

Overall, this game was great and I had a lot of fun playing it. The story is engaging and well written. The characters (besides Dante & Virgil) are actually likeable and have unique personalities. The game play is very addicting and the upgrade system is decent. There is a decent variety of enemies and I will definitely be doing another play through. So the game has a lot of replay value for me. 

My two main gripes that I have with this game, is that the controls are good but the 3D camera perspective is just annoying. I had a lot of times where the camera would glitch into a wall or during crazy fights it just cant keep up with the hectic combat. Now I did get used to it, so its not a deal breaker but just gets annoying at times. Lastly, there are a few boss fights that it does not clearly show you what you have to do to beat them. I find this annoying, now yes, I can just play and figure it out but then it costs me more health than its worth. This is especially annoying for the final boss battle. 

Anyways, the game is great and totally worth the money! A+

115204131.review:
[h1]Edgy Woohoo Emo Kid Adventure[/h1]

Sorry, no pizza here.
Yes, you read it right, our old Dante is replaced by this crawny, rough and edgy Dante who looks like Justin Bieber in his early 20.
The game presentation is totally different from the previous game, the characters, the world, the enemy designs, everything is brand new.
Disclaimer : I've only played 2 games from this series, that is this game and the other is DMC3


This game is a reboot of Devil May Cry series, which later got un-rebooted because of negative reception for the game's direction. But does the game really deserve it's own hate?

Personally speaking I enjoy every aspects of the game, minus the presentation. Do note that I've just only completed the vanilla game, which means I haven't play the [spoiler]Vergil Downfall[/spoiler] DLC. Here are the breakdowns for the game


[b]Gameplay[/b]
[list]
[*]The gameplay is solid and fun, there's some platforming segments that (depending on the player) might add more variety to the game, or will become a nuisance during their playthrough
[*]New gameplay formula which introduce both demon and angel weapon style with their own use
[*]Multiple enemies with their own gimmick that you need to overcome
[*]Challenge room for those who seek specialized challenge
[*]Some level design is really good and totally different from the previous entries
[*]Some things that I find bad from gameplay aspect are : 
[/list]
[olist]
[*]There are some elite mooks with special gimmick which will hinder your own pace
[*]Lack of bosses to fight, [spoiler]with the total of only 6 bosses to fight[/spoiler], some are interesting and yet some are quite tedious
[*]No lock on feature which will make the game's combat mildly frustrating since you can't target specific enemy
[/olist]
I can't stress enough how much I find the game's core combat gameplay are way more fun than 3 (yes, yes, boo me)

[b]Story[/b]
It's your generic "this world is controlled by a demon, we must fight for our freedom" story. With it's own twist of course. But yes, compared to the other game's story. It's kinda weak, but still enjoyable overall. Since you know, this game used to be a new foundation for the new rebooted series.

[b]Music[/b]
It's not like the music is bad per se for me. It's just I got too focused on the combat so I don't really pay attention to the game's soundtrack. So it's not bad but kinda forgettable? Also heavy metal music is a hit or miss for me.

[b]Graphic[/b]
For a soon to be a decade old game, the game's overall graphic still holds on. The presentation of the game however is come down to your own preference, especially if you've played and enjoy the game's other entry.


All in all, DmC Devil May Cry is a solid entry for those who wants to get into Hack and Slash game genre. It's fun, it's stylish, and it's crying on the corner because fewer people likes it.

It's a bum that the definitive edition that fix some of the issues I mentioned above isn't on PC.

115190213.review:
[h1]The Unbiased part...Demon Dancing...[h1]

This game succeeds on many fronts and falters in others, while it has many problems with the identity of the dante character it knows what it wants to portray, and does it with mid 2000's cringey badass sensibilities.

>weapons and combos
all reasonable and satisfying, being able to chain combos from one weapon into another provided great depth and variety which i loved, shame about the demon/angel evades needing too many buttons to properly activate for me (this meant i never really used them) but i played this on M+KB  so perhaps i was asking for it. 

>levels and maps
beautiful colour scheming in most levels with nice detail and lovely white text appearing from the antagonist narrator, which is a first for me in a game but gave it a nice sense of everyone vs you. maps had bonuses to discover and optional challenges to complete and while i did not find them all i did all that i could, note that some are too difficult in the current time and are designed to be done later when you are replaying the game with the entire arsenal at hand. the art of the levels is somewhere you will not be dissatisfied

>characters and story 
dante and his gang are okay looking, kinda punkie, kinda street nice blend, kat did not inspire any strong feelings however. enemies are the "mechanical" silent hill sorta variety, imagine a steampunk gothic demon angel with a mask, a few skelly men and a few rats are thrown in aswell. 

the bosses are all good, some even amazing (im looking at bob specifically here) very fresh takes on boss fights in my view, and none were TOO HARD? i would not know this is a first time playthrough review so i didn't have the hardest difficulty unlocked so i just played on the hardest one from the start of my save file.

but the big plot.. welll? i mean kill the "evil guy" is the main goal and your gang gotta set up a way to do this, no real big character moments, some memories regained and dante is nicer to folks in the end but if you want deep lore this is not the genre for you. granted i enjoyed watching the cutscenes as a break from the combat.

[h1]....the biased part....[h1]
>beats and bops, riffs and rocks
i LOVE THIS SOUNDTRACK, when i heard the heavy metal combat tunes after obtaining the arbiter i knew the 6 bucks i spent on this game were justified, the unique combo shines in most areas of gameplay and serve to hype you up to fight and damn does it get my blood pumping. and this is biased since i love the music genres they are using in general so its only natural i disclose that i will not be crapping on the ost of this game very far from it.
the boss themes are all exquisite as well, give it a shot you will not regret it.

113872658.review:
Now that we live in the good timeline where things got course corrected, we can look at DmC more open-minded and forget all the negative biases that fairly and unfairly were casted against it. This being the first time I played it, I found it had several good game play ideas, with the problem some get in the way of it's own intentions. 

From the top, the story is a bigger focus than before, for the negative. Not only you have to suffer many in-game slow walky parts that we all got sick off even before the eight gen, there's a couple of missions that are almost lacking in combat or have it focused right after several of these guided points. A real flow-killer.
And the story itself is questionable at best, and I'm being generous. I absolutely dislike the inclusion of angels, as it robs the series own title of weight, on top of putting Donte on a level that makes him ironically less empathetic. 
Donte himself is as much of an ass as the memes would make you think, but the moments that start showing his character development are surprisingly well done, and come across as genuine, especially from the voice performance. Vorgil is the one who really gets trashed around, having too little of his own reinvented personality, with his euphoric presence and women's rights advocacy being the highlights of a disappointing character.

Gameplay wise it's an even more mixed bag. Several moves and weapon uses are streamlined, and it is possible to have both fun encounters with decent combo variety, the controls aren't as bad as originally thought and the animations do enough of a job to sell every impact. Weapon switching is easy to get used to as well, and several mechanics are experimented and added, to the point we would see some elements inspiring 5 down the line, such as the grapple.
However, there's many nagging issues, from color coded enemies, no lock on (a can of worms), the lack of styles means some actions like rainstorm require pressing two buttons instead of just Circle/B, an overly generous style meter, an almost annoying focus on platforming in some admittedly pretty and creative environments and very simple boss fights with too many repetitive elements. At times you'll be frustrated with some encounters, or flat out almost tired of these floating paths.

As negative as that last part might seem, the gameplay is still decent enough that it carries the game and maybe a replay or two, and if you enjoy some cringe the plot is so obscenely over the top it can have it's genuine appeal. Given the fact that it goes cheap and there isn't much of a reason to be upset anymore, I can encourage giving it a sincere try. Maybe you'll like it enough, appreciate what's good, and laugh at the bad. 

Also I highly recommend playing it in Spanish for the best experience.

113716855.review:
A game that's way better than how hardcore Devil May Cry fans whine about it, and is genuinely fun, but ultimately kind of disappointing.

The combat is fun. The basic flow of hold right/left trigger to use different weapons, then use the d-pad to switch between these weapons is surprisingly entertaining. The enemies that can only be attacked while using specific weapons are annoying, but it's only in the later difficulties that they pop up to the point where it kind of sucks and breaks up the flow of combat. The music is also a standout. While nothing I'd listen to in my own free time, it fits the mood of the game perfectly, and gets you appropriately hyped up for the many fights the game has to offer.

But really the disappointing thing is the story. You should never play a DMC game for the story, but the general setup of Dante and Vergil teaming up to fight an evil fox news host and an evil demonic banker who wants to control the world through poverty has a lot of promise. This is ultimately squandered because both Dante and Vergil are completely boring. Dante's only real character development is he falls for the graffiti artist love interest. Vergil basically never does anything but hack some computers and shoot a pregnant woman through the stomach with a high powered rifle. By the end of the game I was honestly felt more for the evil demonic banker whose wife and child were killed by our protagonists, than our actual protagonists.

Another disappointment is the setting. The game immediately sets out giving you this whole human world/demon world thing that feels like They Live, where all the billboards display capitalist propaganda, and the surroundings shift and warp into these twisted views of what's actually around Dante. This seems awesome. In reality, this is really only used in the first level, and throughout 70% of the game you're basically just going through sewers or nondescript "hell" areas that just look like big caves with rocks floating around. To be fair you do go through an evil office building, an evil dance club, and very briefly an evil fox news broadcast, but these are all underutilized and extremely short.

Going further, the whole feel of DMC is ruined. There's basically like 5 bosses in the whole game, where most DMC levels typically end with a big boss fight. The bosses themselves are usually pretty fun, but you can count them on one hand, and most are extremely gimmicky. Most DMC cutscenes also typically feature extremely stupid, but entertaining, choreography where our protagonists are surfing on missiles, flamenco dancing through demonic attacks, and generally doing extremely goofy but entertaining stunts. In this game, there's basically one example of this, where a nude Dante gets dressed in one motion while the shitty camper RV he lives in is being flipped around while random items keep getting in the way of seeing his dong. Aside from this, Dante basically just walks around and talks in the cutscenes.

Taken as a complete reboot of Devil May Cry and considered completely apart from the other games in the series, it's really not that bad. The story is disappointing, the use of the initially clever setting sucks, but the combat is really fun. Based solely on this I still recommend the game. Who knows, maybe if Ninja Theory got to do another sequel they could've ironed out the issues over everything around the combat. It's just not really a good Devil May Cry game, though not just because they changed Dante and Vergil like people loved to whine about when the game first released.

Oh, also the platforming absolutely sucks, and the fact that they cram it into every level, even basing special "challenge arenas" around it, is terrible.

112627046.review:
So I picked up the complete pack of [b]Devil May Cry: Cursed Ninja Edition[/b] during a Capcom sale when it was $10 so I could have something to hold me over while I wait for something else to release.

Devil May Cry: Cursed Ninja Edition is basically an attempt to reboot the famous Devil May Cry series, but instead of being developed by Capcom, it was made by a more Western company, Ninja Theory, who either didn't understand or hated various aspects (Probably both) of the original series. This is why I refer to this game as things like "The Cursed Ninja Version" and it's a game that falls into the category of "Not necessarily a bad game, but a bad Devil May Cry game". Devil May Cry: The Cursed Ninja Edition is perfectly enjoyable in its own league and is by no means a flawless game.

The combat is very fluid and smooth in the cursed ninja version, each enemy had their own unique and interesting weaknesses until you get introduced to the "Elemental" enemy types which can only be killed by using either angelic or demonic weapons you'll acquire through your journey... these enemies would have been better implemented if their elemental affiliation wasn't so strict. On top of that, enemy variety is a bit lacking and a lot of them look pretty samey.

The platforming? My gosh I honestly love the platforming in Devil May Cry games (except devil may cry 1), and the cursed ninja version actually does platforming sections pretty well outside of the timed sequences. They're neither too complicated nor too easy, and just kindof in this really nice middle ground. It's a fun time killer between combat arenas.

Now the story and the writing is where the cursed ninja version takes a lot of oofs. There's a lot more needless floof and more scenes that feel like someone just wanted to throw in some extra cussing just for the sake of having extra cussing. Nobody needed a cutscene where half the words were the f-bomb, nobody needed a cutscene that basically showcased the bad guy banging his mistress. If the original series didn't need that stuff in order to be good, then you didn't either.

Last thing I gotta note here is basically all the levels take place in limbo. Now limbo's design is frankly pretty cool, but nearly every level takes place [i]in[/i] limbo like it's "Okay cool I was in limbo and I fought my way out" then next level is like "I'm being dragged into limbo... again..." and it's like that for almost every level which to me feels like a cop-out way of throwing the player into the fight every time.

So can I recommend it? I mean if the aforementioned negatives don't bother you and you get the complete pack for $10 during a sale then... maybe? It's a tough one. I can't really go either way here. It's fun but it's also the stereotypical crappy reboot/remake of its franchise... I'd easily recommend the 5 mainline games over this in a heartbeat.

112621515.review:
This is one of my all time favorite games. I've played and gotten every achievement on both PlayStation and Xbox and just picked it up on steam because the sale price couldn't be passed up. I'll end up getting every achievement on here too. 

The gameplay is possibly the best of any Devil May Cry game. If you've ever played a Ninja Theory game you would know their controls are always tight and everything plays perfectly. 

The story is mediocre. But this is a DMC game and the story is pretty bad in most of them. The biggest complaint I see people give this game is that the "Changed Dante".  But this isn't one of the main DMC titles and it isn't supposed to be the same Dante. Capcom had Ninja Theory re-imagine the Devil May Cry story. They took aspects from several of the core DMC games and told their own story using the characters and some of the basic plot points. It takes itself a little more seriously than other games in the DMC franchise and is a darker take on some of the themes. I did enjoy the story telling but that isn't why you play a DMC game. These games are all about over the top action and this has it in spades. 

The soundtrack is fantastic and most of the soundtrack was made by Combichrist. So it has that industrial metal sound that permeates the rest of the series, just also sounding more in line with the more serious tone of this game. 

If you're one of the people who refused to play it at launch because "they made Dante emo" you missed out on a gem. I highly recommend giving this game a shot when it's on sale. It won't disappoint.

112522017.review:
TLDR: Bad writing, good move set mixed with awful enemy design. Really only worth it if you don't have any of the mainline games to play, and for some reason this one is $5. Or if you're a franchise fan and want to experience every game.

Story & Writing:
DmC DeViL mAy CrY is one of the worst written, overly edgy, easily-recognizable-as-"PS3"-era games I've ever played. The overall color palette is as dry as it's writing, the characters as uninteresting and frustrating as it's enemy design. It's still got a core gameplay loop that's fun for a bit, until you have to keep fighting the same awful enemies over and over.

If you love the mainline series, this game will piss you off. Skip the cutscenes.
Actually, if you play this game at all, skip the cutscenes.
The story is a boring pile of garbage, of desperately trying to differentiate itself from the OG, but it seems to be that one clingy friend who cries every time you don't talk to them for 5 minutes. It tries so hard to be it's own thing, constantly saying "Fuck the mainline series", and then pulling a majority of it's ideas from the main series. The story ends up doing a stinger off a ledge into the pitfall of the PS3's generation of "EDGE OVER EVERYTHING" as an attempt to have some sort of draw to it. It really just doesn't work. It's poorly written, generic edge. A constant theme through the writing of this game.

STARRING:
Dante: The unenjoyable, lame, embarrassing protagonist to play. Hates white hair! Got drip tho.
Vergil: The unenjoyable, lame, embarrassing "IOU" for where a second main character should be. Got drip tho.
Edgy Female PS3 Character: Edgy Female PS3 Character.

The writing in this game is like a 12 year old picked up their first M rated game and thought saying "FUCK" was the coolest thing since that one time Shadow the Hedgehog said "DAMN" (in his famous PS2 title, "Shadowman Hedge Trimmer"). Here's a slice of the absolute peak of writing that you will get in this title:

"The world is at last your bitch. As am I."
And
"Fuck you!"
"Fuck you!"
"FUCK YOU!"

Funny to laugh at, but these (mostly unintentional) funny moments in the writing are as rare as someone actually using a Yellow Orb in this game.

Gameplay:
DmC DeViL mAkE CoOkIe has the typical trappings of the franchise. Weapon switching, air combos, spamming stinger because there's no sprint button, it's all there. Although it feels a bit less polished than mainline, it's still a passable game in terms of your own actions. They've decided to actually put some effort into something, and with that comes genuinely fun ways to string combos with multiple weapons together. Included are Nero's hooking mechanics from 4/5, which is always fun. But this is all bundled in with a shitty upgrade tree that mostly extends moves' DMG, or for longer moves, how long they last. Quite lame.

The player control / combat mechanics may have some good ideas, but the enemies do not. For some reason, Ninja Theory decided it would be a good idea to make it so that there's enemies that you can only hit with specific weapon types, and if you hit them with any other weapon, (even if unintentional because there's no lock-on mechanic in this game,) you dink. It's massively frustrating. It's a cool idea in concept, the color coded enemy-to-weapon thing, but in gameplay it just becomes an annoyance to dink constantly because you didn't see the blue colored guy through the red filter on the screen that makes every enemy look red regardless if they're color coded or not.
They could have fixed this by possibly just making it so that you could only stagger enemies of that color with weapons of the same color, or reduced damage with weapons of other colors.

The enemies themselves also massively suck. Out of every DMC game, this has to have the highest count of infuriating enemies to fight. Teleporting eneimes, shielding eneimes, unstaggerable eneimes, specific-weakpoint-or-dink enemies, weapon-specific enemies, sometimes multiple combinations in one enemy! What a thrill. The game tries so hard to make you NOT enjoy the actual effort they put into Dante's main moveset here. I genuinely got to a point where, regardless of actually enjoying the combos, I just did not want to complete this game. It's like having your favorite pair of underwear on, but you shit in them 30 minutes ago. I'm happy I'm in them, just in the circumstances of currently wearing them, I'd rather be at home playing DMC 3/5.

The boss fights are pretty lame, as well. I wouldn't say they're poorly designed. That insinuates they were designed at all. Every one of them is about opening up a weak point, hitting the weak point, the weak point gets hidden, repeat. Generic Video Game boss. The exception to this rule is "Bob". Gotta love Bob. His fight itself is no different, however there is a cute little section that pays a slight homage to the OG trilogy, which was neat. Then I got back into the main fight and wanted to castrate myself.

Graphics:
Honestly, this game looks pretty good. I like the Limbo morphing around the world, there's lots of stuff done in real-time in this game with how the world transforms in the Limbo dimension. The mo-cap is generally impressive for the time, although you will quickly neglect this and laugh at how awful the line delivery and writing is during cutscenes. This game might make me wanna castrate myself, but at least it doesn't make me wanna gouge my eyes out too.

Music:
Yeah, there's definitely music in this game. Aside from one song, it's just aight. Nothing I'll listen to outside of the game.

Anyway, my Adderall is wearing off.
GOOD POINTS:
Dante's moveset, visuals.
NEGATIVE POINTS:
Literally everything else.

People seem to think this game has gotten too much hate, but I don't even think with time this game is that great. If any of the mainline games didn't exist, if Bayonetta didn't exist, these points would not change. Every area of this game contradicts or fights against itself. DmC is just a game that hates itself. Guess it's pretty relevant for the PS3 edge it's bursting with.

Sarcasm aside
I gave this game a fair shot, but I really don't think it's worth much. I had moments of fun, enjoyed (and was honestly intrigued) by the visuals at points, and the combat is interesting to fuck around with, but I really don't think it's worth it at all. Especially with 4 other solid games in the franchise easily available on steam. Maybe if Ninja Theory got a second shot they could do better? Not gonna happen.

Edit: Finished Vergil DLC. Same issues apply, but in less quantity overall. Still, this DLC is extremely short and not worth the price of admission.

110595653.review:
Is DMC: Devil May Cry a good Devil May Cry title? No. 

I maintain the stance that this is a very good game, Ninja Theory are one of best companies out there for making combat based titles, but this is not Dante, this is not Virgil, this isn't the campy demon hunter we all know and love and grew up with. From a strictly mechanical standpoint, the game plays great, love the platforming, love the combat, love the level design, but the characters and plot really leave a lot to be desired.

I would recommend this game if you're looking for a good combat title with a silly story that you can sink about 8 hours of your life into if you're just looking for a single run, otherwise it has all the usual DMC bits and bobs like the bloody palace, trying to unlock every move and so on. 

It's fun, but it's not Devil May Cry.

110422264.review:
Minimal spoilers on game mechanics, this review is from someone who will never leaderboard.

If you can get past the misogyny and Bollywood level of ridiculousness that peaks in the first level, then this game is a fun journey.  I'm glad I kept going to finish my steam cards, because I wound up finishing the game on the normal (Devil Hunter) difficulty.  The story is cheesy, but good enough to hold your interest between missions, which are varied enough to not feel like linearity is a bad thing.  And ignore the style scores on your first (only?) playthrough.

It's a brawler game with combos that seem to focus more on using specific buttons than perfect timing (in contrast to a true hack 'n slash clicker like Diablo).  There are some needs for perfect timing for the advanced combos, yet I just didn't use those much and hacked away at the enemies.  There's some modest platforming between fights but nothing too awful (stay in angel mode for that second glide).

Upgrades can be reversed, so feel free to experiment.  I mostly upgraded the primary abilities and initial devil/angel weapons (even the guns are weak).  I realized way too late in the game that you can just use 1, 2, and 3 to toggle between the human/devil/angel modes, rather than holding E or Q.  Since some enemies can only be damaged in a specific mode, it's good remembering that orange = devil and blue = angel.

If you get stuck, you can always go back and replay earlier levels to finish acquiring upgrade resources and items (before trying to push again, with the newer upgrades/items).  The game gives you new weapons and abilities through the story, so some early levels are built so that you can only unlock some things by replaying them later.  Upgrades persist between sessions, as does the act of having picked up the same upgrade (can't grab the same thing twice).  I'm the last guy to play a player-vs-player fighting game because my reflexes suck, and I still made it through the entire game on normal (Demon Hunter) difficulty without needing to double back.

When you restart a mission, or checkpoint, you restart with full health.  And there's a checkpoint between every arena, which is quite often.  So it's actually best to not use Gold orbs or health at all.  When the game asks if you want to revive, just choose no and then on the next screen choose "Continue".  You'll restart the current arena/fight, but come back with full health.  Save the gold orbs for a really tough boss fight instead, and money for health bar increases!  If you ever 'git gud' then you can replay without dying in the first place.

Every enemy has one or more weaknesses, some that they tell you about a few missions after they are introduced.  Tyrants (the big fat guys), for example, can be dodged when they charge (shift and a direction), then you simply use a grapple (E, in demon mode) from behind them to pull them onto their back like a stuck turtle.  That usually gives you enough time to land one or two arbiter slams (E+F) on them and repeat.  I wish there were more reliable guides on how to take down each enemy type.

Going into this I knew I wouldn't commit the time to earn all of the achievements, but ended my run with a 'good enough' 34% (mostly story achievements but definitely a few from just using weapons, before starting Vergil's Downfall).  At 9.5 hours for the average player, wait for one of the $7.50 sales.

Edit: Vregil's Downfall was underwhelming, but brought my achievements up to 39% to complete once on easy (Human) without any extra effort.
